"(Bloomberg) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party is poised to lose its majority in parliament, forcing him to rely on allies to form a government. It's a stunning blow to a leader who has dominated Indian politics since he first took power a decade ago.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 241 seats, short of the 272 needed to form a government and well behind the 303 it won in the 2019 election. {"uri": "2024-06-375231784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "07:32:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T07:32:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T03:48:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://arab.news/5gtvf", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on", "body": "If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister\n\nNEW DELHI: Indians began voting Saturday in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10 percent of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14 percent of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nOn Thursday, after finishing his election campaign, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80 percent of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8156619544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "13:03:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T13:03:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T13:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-pm-modis-decade/article_dbd9acbf-901b-51b8-94f4-67967d968452.html", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on PM Modi's decade in power", "body": "Members of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness wait in a queue to cast their votes outside a polling station during the seventh and last phase of general election, in Kolkata, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- A six-week-long national election in India that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power ended Saturday as Indians cast ballots in the last phase of voting.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory. It completed a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost poll surveys show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violates election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, India.", {"uri": "2024-06-375718587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "20:17:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T20:17:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T16:30:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://arab.news/mrsha", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on PM", "body": "Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric during his campaign in a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base\n\nNEW DELHI: India's six-week-long national election came to an end Saturday as the last of the country's hundreds of millions of voters went to the polls for a contest that's widely seen as a referendum on Hindu Nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase election, candidates criss-crossed the country, pollworkers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. Now all that's left is to wait for the results, which are expected to be announced Tuesday.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost poll surveys show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14 percent of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10 percent of the world's population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for five-year terms in parliament.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80 percent of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nModi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8156954218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "18:52:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T18:52:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T18:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/modi-projected-to-retain-power-as-voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election", "title": "Modi projected to retain power as voting ends in the last round of India's election", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's 6-week-long national election came to an end Saturday with most exit polls projecting Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to extend his decade in power with a third consecutive term.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase election, candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. Now all that's left is to wait for the results, which are expected to be announced Tuesday.\n\nREAD MORE: Millions vote in India's grueling election with Modi's party likely to win 3rd term\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls by major television news channels projected Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies were leading over the broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party. Most exit polls projected BJP and its allies could win more than 350 seats out of 543 -- far ahead of the 272 seats needed to form the next government.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14 percent of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nREAD MORE: Modi accused of hate speech for calling Muslims 'infiltrators' at Indian election rally\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10 percent of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80 percent of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nModi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, India.", {"uri": "8156271815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "07:47:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T07:47:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T07:46:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/politics/voting-begins-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in-power-896791", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "NEW DELHI: A six-week-long national election in India that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power neared its end Saturday as the last phase of voting began.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covers 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory. It will complete a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047 . But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violates election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy , his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state .\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent .\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat , with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "deccanchronicle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deccan {"uri": "8156830011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "16:33:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T16:33:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T16:33:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2024-06-01/voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in-power", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "India's six-week-long national election came to an end Saturday with most exit polls projecting Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to extend his decade in power with a third consecutive term.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase election, candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. Now all that's left is to wait for the results, which are expected to be announced Tuesday.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls by major television news channels projected Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies were leading over the broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party. Most exit polls projected BJP and its allies could win more than 350 seats out of 543 -- far ahead of the 272 seats needed to form the next government.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat. Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January.\n\nModi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "latimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Los Angeles Times"}, {"uri": "2024-06-375491209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "13:40:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T13:40:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T12:58:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/world/voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-pm-modis-decade/article_d62ae6cd-360a-5ea9-a3fb-ef752e1bd8e3.html", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on PM Modi's decade in power", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's six-week-long national election came to an end Saturday as the last of the country's hundreds of millions of voters went to the polls for a contest that's widely seen as a referendum on Hindu Nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase election, candidates criss-crossed the country, pollworkers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. Now all that's left is to wait for the results, which are expected to be announced Tuesday.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost poll surveys show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for five-year terms in parliament.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nModi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, India.", {"uri": "2024-06-375569411", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "15:39:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T15:39:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T15:33:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in/article_12bf3a16-06ae-55f8-ac44-0fc5d016c482.html", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's 6 -week-long national election came to an end Saturday with most exit polls projecting Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to extend his decade in power with a third consecutive term.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase election, candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. Now all that's left is to wait for the results, which are expected to be announced Tuesday.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls by major television news channels projected Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies were leading over the broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party. Most exit polls them projected BJP and its allies could win more than 350 seats out of 543 -- far ahead of the 272 seats needed to form the next government.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nModi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, India.", {"uri": "8156601994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "12:46:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T12:46:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T12:45:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/01/voting-ends-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-pm-modis-decade-in-power/", "title": "Voting ends in the last round of India's election, a referendum on PM Modi's decade in power - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Sheikh Saaliq And Krutika Pathi, The Associated Press on June 1, 2024.\n\nSUBSCRIBE NOW NEW DELHI (AP) - A six-week-long national election in India that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power ended Saturday as Indians cast ballots in the last phase of voting. The election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister. The seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory. It completed a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world's population - were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office. Most poll surveys show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day. Modi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people. After campaigning ended on Thursday, Modi went to a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violates election rules as the campaigning period has ended. When the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term. Since first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest. At the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state. But as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent. Pre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated. In Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party. \"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar. In this election, Modi's BJP - which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts - sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway. The BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes. Instead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls. This was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously. In 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers. But things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost. \"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\"\u009d said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst. ___ Associated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter ending campaigning on Thursday, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nAssociated Press video journalist Shonal Ganguly contributed from Kolkata, India.", {"uri": "2024-06-375050902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "01:46:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T01:46:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T21:33:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-31/voting-begins-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in-power", "title": "Voting Begins in the Last Round of India's Election, a Referendum on Modi's Decade in Power", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Indians began voting Saturday in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-06-375134921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "04:56:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T04:56:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T01:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/31/voting-begins-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in-power/", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "Voters wait to cast their votes at a polling station during the last round of a six week-long national election near Dharamshala, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of [...]\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Indians began voting Saturday in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nOn Thursday, after finishing his election campaign, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": {"uri": "8156133429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "05:30:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T05:30:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T05:29:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/31/voting-begins-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election/", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "Ashwini Bhatia / AP\n\nVoters wait to cast their votes at a polling station during the last round of a six week-long national election near Dharamshala, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters more than 10% of the world's population were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years.\n\nBy Sheikh Saaliq and Krutika Pathi, Associated Press\n\nFriday, May 31, 2024 | 10:14 p.m.\n\nNEW DELHI -- Indians began voting Saturday in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nOn Thursday, after finishing his election campaign, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Sun"}, {"uri": "8156234609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "07:10:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T07:10:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T07:10:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2024/06/01/3096356/voting-begins-in-last-round-of-india-s-election-a-referendum-on-modi-s-decade-in-power", "title": "Voting Begins in Last Round of India's Election, A Referendum on Modi's Decade in Power - Other Media news - Tasnim News Agency", "body": "The election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister, AP reported.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10 percent of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14 percent of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nOn Thursday, after finishing his election campaign, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80 percent of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "tasnimnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarising rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter ending campaigning on Thursday, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honouring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early on Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius. Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energise his core Hindu voter base.
