If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nYesterday's seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world's population - were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party.\n\nThe votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress.\n\nHistoric election: Monks standing in a queue to cast their ballot at a polling station on the seventh and final phase of voting in India's general election, in Kolkata. -- AFP\n\nHe has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047.\n\nBut the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarising rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter ending campaigning on Thursday, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honouring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims.\n\nIndia's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party.\n\nThey have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the "body": "Seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in powerful lower house of Parliament.\n\nIndians have began voting in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India's history.\n\nIf Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million voters -- more than 10 percent of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years.\n\nMore than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party [BJP] leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party.\n\nThe votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nScorching summer temperatures with unusually high heatwaves have compounded voter fatigue in the majority-Hindu country, where unemployment and inflation are the main concerns for {"uri": "8156660378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "13:42:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T13:42:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T13:40:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41407523.html", "title": "Voting ends in last round of India's election", "body": "The results of the election, which is widely seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power, are expected to be announced on Tuesday.\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, he will be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost poll surveys show Mr Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leading over the broad opposition alliance that is challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nMr Modi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Mr Modi used polarising rhetoric in speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Mr Modi went to a memorial site honouring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Mr Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Mr Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Mr Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Mr Modi over his politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite brisk economic growth under Mr Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world's population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for five-year terms in parliament.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early on Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34C. Mr Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\nIn this election, Mr Modi's BJP - which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts - sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Mr Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nMr Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energise his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Mr Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Mr Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls after his government launched air strikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Mr Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covers 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory. It will complete a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8156656006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "13:37:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T13:37:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T13:36:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/01/voting-ends-in-last-round-of-indias-election/", "title": "Voting ends in last round of India's election", "body": "The vote is widely seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nIndia's six-week-long national election has ended as the last of the country's hundreds of millions of voters cast their ballots.\n\nCandidates travelled across the country during the multi-phase election as poll workers hiked to remote villages and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat.\n\nThe results of the election, which is widely seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power, are expected to be announced on Tuesday.\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, he will be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost poll surveys show Mr Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) leading over the broad opposition alliance that is challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nMr Modi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Mr Modi used polarising rhetoric in speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Mr Modi went to a memorial site honouring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Mr Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Mr Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Mr Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Mr Modi over his politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite brisk economic growth under Mr Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world's population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for five-year terms in parliament.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early on Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34C. Mr Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\nIn this election, Mr Modi's BJP - which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts - sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Mr Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nMr Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energise his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Mr Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Mr Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls after his government launched air strikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Mr Modi's political challengers a potential opportunity.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Express & Star"}, But it turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as Mr Modi used polarising rhetoric in speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter campaigning ended on Thursday, Mr Modi went to a memorial site honouring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it violated election rules as the campaigning period has ended.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Mr Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Mr Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nA group of voters pose for a photograph next to a cutout portrait of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi (AP Photo/Rajesh Kumar Singh)\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Mr Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Mr Modi over his politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite brisk economic growth under Mr Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory, completing a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world's population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for five-year terms in parliament.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early on Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34C. Mr Modi was challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\nIn this election, Mr Modi's BJP - which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts - sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Mr Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nMuslim women stand in a queue to cast their votes in the seventh and final phase of national elections, in Varanasi, India (AP Photo/Rajesh Kumar Singh)\n\nMr Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls, in a move seen as a bid to energise his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the absence of a single big-ticket campaign issue, which Mr Modi has relied on to power previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Mr Modi's status as a political outsider with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. {"uri": "8155965164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "01:47:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T01:47:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T01:46:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13482791/Voting-begins-round-Indias-election-referendum-Modis-decade-power.html", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum...", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) - Indians began voting Saturday in the last round of a six week-long national election that is a referendum on the country\u00b4s Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi\u00b4s decade in power.\n\nThe election is considered one of the most consequential in India\u00b4s history. If Modi wins, he\u00b4ll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country\u00b4s first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters - more than 10% of the world\u00b4s population - were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that\u00b4s challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi\u00b4s campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country\u00b4s Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India\u00b4s 1.4 billion people.\n\nOn Thursday, after finishing his election campaign, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nVoters wait to cast their votes at a polling station during the last round of a six week-long national election near Dharamshala, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters more than 10% of the world's population were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. (AP Photo/Ashwini Bhatia)\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India\u00b4s standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world\u00b4s fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India\u00b4s democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn this election, Modi\u00b4s BJP - which controls much of India\u00b4s Hindi-speaking northern and central parts - sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country\u00b4s eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi\u00b4s status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi\u00b4s political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\nPolling officials check and seal an electronic voting machine before they allow voters to cast their votes at a polling station during the last round of a six week-long national election near Dharamshala, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters more than 10% of the world's population were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. (AP Photo/Ashwini Bhatia)\n\nVoters wait to cast their votes during the last round of a six week-long national election in Kolkata, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters more than 10% of the world's population were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. (AP Photo/Bikas Bas)\n\nVoters wait to cast their votes at a polling station during the last round of a six week-long national election near Dharamshala, India, Saturday, June 1, 2024. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters more than 10% of the world's population were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. (AP Photo/Ashwini Bhatia)\n\nElection officials collect polling materials at a distribution center ahead of the seventh and last round of polling in India's national election in Dharamshala, India, Thursday, May 30, 2024. (AP Photo/Ashwini Bhatia)\n\nOfficials check electronic voting machines kept inside a secured room prior to distribution to polling centers on the eve of the seventh and final phase of national elections in Amritsar, India, Friday, May 31, 2024. (AP Photo/Prabhjot Gill)\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, left, flanked by Bharatiya Janata Party leader Suvendu Adhikari waves to greet his supporters from a vehicle during a roadshow ahead of the last phase of elections in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, May 28, 2024. {"uri": "2024-06-377973279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:14:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:14:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:12:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/asia-pacific/20240604-india-begins-vote-count-world-biggest-election-narendra-modi-poised-win-third-term", "title": "India begins vote count in world's biggest election with Modi poised to win third term", "body": "India began counting more than 640 million votes Tuesday in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe six-week election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nRead moreTrust deficit at the heart of India's electronic voting debate\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout was around 66% on average across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nRead more'Ugly speech' but not a surprise: Modi accused of anti-Muslim rhetoric on campaign trail\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarising rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energise his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [], "concepts": If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nThe seventh round of polls covers 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory. It will complete a national election to fill all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Nearly 970 million voters -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to elect a new parliament for five years. More than 8,300 candidates ran for the office.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nRead more on FRANCE 24 English\n\nRead also:\n\nIndia's animated {"uri": "2024-06-378223486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:07:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:07:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:51:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/modis-coalition-leads-in-a-majority-of-seats-in-early-count-but-opposition-is-stiffer/article_1cbafe49-26f9-550c-a343-0145765ed575.html", "title": "Modi's coalition leads in a majority of seats in early count but opposition is stiffer than expected", "body": "Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) party supporters cheer as they follow proceedings of the vote counting at their party office in Chennai, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was set to take all day. Modi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term -- even as the race tightened and the early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures were expected to change.\n\nThe \"Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 7%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAssociated Press writer David Rising contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, {"uri": "8156911349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "18:03:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T18:03:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T18:01:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2724954/", "title": "Voting ends in final round of Indian elections, a referendum on Prime Minister Modi's decade in power - ExBulletin", "body": "NEW DELHI Indiasix-week national electionsVoting ended Saturday as the country's last hundreds of millions of voters went to the polls in a poll widely seen as a referendum on Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power.\n\nDuring the grueling, multi-phase elections, candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers visited remote villages and voters queued for hours in sweltering heat. All that remains is to wait for the results, which should be announced on Tuesday.\n\nThis election is considered one of the most important in Indian history. If Modi wins, he will be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading the broad opposition alliance challenging them, led by the Congress party. Votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModis' campaign began on the basis of an agenda of economic progress, with a vow to uplift the poor and make India a countrydeveloped country by 2047. But this has become increasingly acute in recent weeks as Modiincreased polarizing rhetoricin inflammatory speeches targeting the country's Muslim minority, which makes up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter the campaign ended Thursday, Modi visited a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint to meditate on national television. The opposition Congress party called it a political stunt and said it had violated election rules even though the campaign period was over.\n\nWhen elections began in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to win another term.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a strong, self-made leader who improved India's standing in the world and credit his business-friendly policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his reign was marked by brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims.Indian democracysay his detractors, is faltering and Modi has increasinglyblurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign progressed, his party faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They attacked Modi because of his Hindu nationalist policies and hope to benefit fromgrowing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, rising food prices and a general feeling that only a small portion of Indians have benefited despite strong economic growth under Modi, which which makes the vote tighter than initially expected.\n\nThe seventh round of voting covered 57 constituencies across seven states and one Union Territory, capping a nationwide election to fill the 543 seats in the powerful lower house of Parliament. Nearly 970 million voters, or more than 10% of the world population. More than 8,300 candidates ran for a five-year term in Parliament.\n\nIn Calcutta, the capital of West Bengal, voters queued outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoidthe scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 93.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Modi was challenged there by state Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, who leads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\nThere is currently a shortage of jobs in the current market. I will vote for the government that can create jobs. And I hope those who cannot find a job will find it, said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modis BJP, which controls much of India's northern and central Hindi-speaking regions. sought to extend their influencemaking inroads into the eastern and southern states of the country, where regional parties have greater influence.\n\nThe BJP is also banking on the consolidation of votes within the Hindu majority, which represents 80% of the population, afterModi opened a much-demanded Hindu templeon the site of a mosque razed in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts say the enthusiasm generated by the temple may not be enough to bring in votes.\n\nModi stepped up his anti-Muslim rhetoric after turnout fell slightly below 2019 figures in the first rounds of 2024 voting, in a move seen as an attempt to energize his Hindu voting base. But analysts say it also reflects the absence of a single major campaign issue, which Modi has relied on to fuel previous campaigns.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider, with plans to crack down on deep-rooted corruption, won over voters disillusioned by decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, heswept the polls on a wave of nationalismafter his government launched airstrikes on rival Pakistan in response to a suicide attack in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving a potential opportunity to Modis' political challengers.\n\nThe opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by focusing the discourse on local issues, like unemployment and the economy. In this election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind, said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, {"uri": "2024-06-377973941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:15:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:15:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:06:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/prime-minister-narendra-modi-s-party-comfortably-leads-in-early-results-from-indias-election/article_cce41e13-305b-55c1-90bd-4049005cc34a.html", "title": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party comfortably leads in early results from India's election", "body": "Bharatiya Janata Party supporters watch the live telecast of proceedings of vote counting at their party office in Chennai, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. India began counting more than 640 million votes Tuesday in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Early leads reported Tuesday by India's Election Commission show incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead over its closest rival.\n\nThree hours into counting, Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP was ahead in 239 constituencies out of 542 parliamentary seats, and has already won one in an uncontested race.\n\nThe main opposition Congress party was leading in 96 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting is expected to go on through the day. A total of some 642 million votes are being counted in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties were leading in 286 constituencies according to the early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which was leading in 197 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in parliament.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nIf the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi. Indian media have had a mixed record in predicting past election results.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66% turnout across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India. But leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and they credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nModi's critics say democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": {"uri": "8160941218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:52:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:52:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:52:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/india-election-modi-s-coalition-leads-in-early-count-but-opposition-is-stiffer-than-expected-1.6912525", "title": "India election: Modi's coalition leads in early count but opposition is stiffer than expected", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was set to take all day. Modi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term -- even as the race tightened and the early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures were expected to change.\n\nThe \"Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5 per cent.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nA worker carries a banner of Bharatiya Janta party featuring Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be put up outside party headquarters in New Delhi, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Dinesh Joshi)\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nA roadside fruit juice seller watches the election results on his mobile phone in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Bikas Das)\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14 per cent of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. {"uri": "8161048554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "11:59:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T11:59:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T11:58:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/7893efecc83fa8225a611f174e6420ee/modi-expected-retain-power-early-india-count-suggests-it", "title": "Modi expected to retain power but early India count suggests it won't be the landslide he hoped for", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome eight hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 231 constituencies and had won 13, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 93 constituencies and had won four.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 277 constituencies and won 15, according to the early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 220 constituencies and had won five.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", {"uri": "2024-06-377825933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:41:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:41:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T02:31:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.orilliamatters.com/world-news/india-begins-counting-votes-in-marathon-election-expected-to-bring-prime-minister-modi-a-third-term-8968992", "title": "India begins counting votes in marathon election expected to bring Prime Minister Modi a third term", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India on Tuesday begun counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout averaged 66% across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will emerge earlier and indicate where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nKrutika Pathi And Sheikh Saaliq, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "orilliamatters.com", {"uri": "8160517807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:17:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:17:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:16:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/world/prime-minister-narendra-modi-s-party-comfortably-leads-in-early-results-from-indias-election/article_b7594cbd-eebe-5ab2-b1a9-b40a31ea1836.html", "title": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party comfortably leads in early results from India's election", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Early leads reported Tuesday by India's Election Commission show incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead over its closest rival.\n\nThree hours into counting, Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP was ahead in 239 constituencies out of 542 parliamentary seats, and has already won one in an uncontested race.\n\nThe main opposition Congress party was leading in 96 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting is expected to go on through the day. A total of some 642 million votes are being counted in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties were leading in 286 constituencies according to the early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which was leading in 197 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in parliament.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nIf the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi. Indian media have had a mixed record in predicting past election results.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66% turnout across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India. But leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and they credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nModi's critics say democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "yakimaherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yakima Herald-Republic"}, "authors":
