{"uri": "8160537691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:32:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/world/modis-party-has-comfortable-lead-over-main-rival-in-early-vote-counting-from-indias-election/article_dd265d3c-e78c-581e-9e8a-72e4650fd07d.html", "title": "Modi's party has comfortable lead over main rival in early vote counting from India's election", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nIf the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nSome three hours into the counting, early leads reported by the Election Commission showed Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead of the main opposition Congress party.\n\nThe preliminary figures showed the BJP ahead in 239 constituencies out of 542 and winning one uncontested race. Congress was leading in 96 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting was to go on throughout the day and early figures were expected to change.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a broad win for Modi's National Democratic Alliance group over an opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66% turnout across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nTemperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing evaporative coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nAP reporter David Rising contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8155990549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "02:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T02:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T02:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/2024/05/31/voting-begins-in-the-last-round-of-indias-election-a-referendum-on-modis-decade-in-power/", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Indians have begun voting in the last round of a six-week-long national election that is a referendum on the country's Hindu nationalist Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power. The election will test the limits of his political dominance as he seeks a third-straight victory. The seventh round of voting in 57 constituencies across seven states and one union territory will complete polling for all 543 seats in the powerful lower house of parliament. Most polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them. The votes will be counted on Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.", "source": {"uri": "keyt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsChannel 3-12"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161179191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:18:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:18:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://baynews9.com/fl/tampa/international/2024/06/04/india-prime-minister-election-narendra-modi", "title": "India's Modi expected to retain power", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as an ongoing count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome 10 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 196 constituencies and had won 45, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 236 constituencies and won 50, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 211 constituencies and had won 19.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much {"uri": "2024-06-378393028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "12:29:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T12:29:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T11:54:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/modi-expected-to-retain-power-but-early-india-count-suggests-it-wont-be-the-landslide/article_cce41e13-305b-55c1-90bd-4049005cc34a.html", "title": "Modi expected to retain power but early India count suggests it won't be the landslide he hoped for", "body": "Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) party supporters cheer as they follow proceedings of the vote counting at their party office in Chennai, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome eight hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 231 constituencies and had won 13, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 93 constituencies and had won four.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 277 constituencies and won 15, according to the early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 220 constituencies and had won five.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8161418304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:54:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:54:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://ici.radio-canada.ca/rci/en/news/2078043/modis-party-leads-in-india-election-but-could-face-stronger-opposition-than-expected", "title": "Modi's party leads in India election but could face stronger opposition than expected | RCI", "body": "Markets swoon on early returns, but it's unclear what percentage of the vote has been tallied so far\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was set to take all day.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term. If Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nWATCH | Great anticipation as India awaits final results in vote:\n\nAfter a historic six-week election, vote counting has begun in India, with many expecting a major win for Narendra Modi, giving him a third consecutive term as the country's prime minister.\n\nNearly 970 million people -- more than 10 per cent of the world's population -- were eligible to vote and turnout averaged 66 per cent, according to official data.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, up from 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's BJP, part of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), led in 196 constituencies and had won 45, according to the early count. The Congress, part of the INDIA alliance, led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nThe election commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures were expected to change.\n\nThe Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule, said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than five per cent.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nModi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nModi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election, said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nEconomic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.\n\nThe campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14 per cent of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters. The opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 C in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air {"uri": "2024-06-378615707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:45:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:45:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:45:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae/news/2024/06/04/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-india-general-election", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lackluster performance from his own party as it faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition.\n\nModi said that his National Democratic Alliance (NDA) will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own - but the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Rahul said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices - the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than 5%.\n\nAssociated Press\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"", "source": {"uri": "gulftoday.ae", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Gulf Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance", {"uri": "2024-06-378580538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:13:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:13:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:51:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/modi-expected-to-get-3rd-term-but-partial-india-count-suggests-narrower-win-that-represents/article_cce41e13-305b-55c1-90bd-4049005cc34a.html", "title": "Modi expected to get 3rd term but partial India count suggests narrower win that represents setback", "body": "Faces of Trinamool Congress Party supporters smeared with green colour celebrate the election results in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party showed a comfortable lead Tuesday, according to early figures reported by India's Election Commission, but was facing a stronger challenge from the opposition than had been expected.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it might not secure a majority on its own, according to the ongoing vote count -- but the prime minister was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi has to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. Despite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 year remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, both sides claimed they had won some sort of victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Gandhi said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8161596711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "18:05:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T18:05:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T18:04:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/06/03/modi-claims-victory-in-indian-election-vows-to-continue-with-his-agenda-despite-drop-in-support/", "title": "Modi claims victory in Indian election, vows to continue with his agenda despite drop in support", "body": "By KRUTIKA PATHI, SHEIKH SAALIQ and DAVID RISING (Associated Press)\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi declared victory Tuesday for his alliance in India's general election, claiming a mandate to push forward with his agenda, even though his party lost seats to a stronger than expected opposition, which pushed back against his mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy,\" Modi told the crowd at his party's headquarters, saying Indian voters had \"shown immense faith\" both in his party and his National Democratic Alliance coalition.\n\nModi's win was only the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister. But also, for the first time since his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it did not secure a majority on its own, meaning he will need the support of other parties in his coalition -- a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nThe party may now be \"heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\nMore than 640 million votes were cast in the marathon election held over a span of six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIn the face of the surprising drop in the BJP's support, the opposition claimed they had also won a victory of sorts, with the main opposition Congress party saying the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nDespite the setback, Modi pledged to make good on his election promise to turn India's economy, the world's third biggest, from its current fifth place, and not shirk with pushing forward with his agenda.\n\nHe said he would advance India's defense production, boost jobs for youth, raise exports and help farmers, among other things.\n\n\"This country will see a new chapter of big decisions. This is Modi's guarantee,\" he said, speaking in the third person.\n\nMany of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 years will also remain locked in place.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years.\n\nAfter winning a record 303 seats in 2019, the BJP appeared unlikely to win more than 240, far short of the 272 needed to form a majority government on its own, with 224 seats won and the lead in 16 constituencies and counting ongoing.\n\nModi's NDA coalition, meantime, was on track to win a combined 286-seat majority, with 263 seats won and leads in 23 races.\n\nThe opposition INDIA coalition appeared as if it would win 230 seats.\n\nFinal figures were not expected until Wednesday, with counting going late into the night. But congratulations for Modi from leaders of regional countries including neighboring Nepal and Bhutan flowed in, while the White House commended India for its \"vibrant democratic process.\"\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance while the economy, one of the world's fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nRahul Gandhi, the main face of the opposition Congress party, said he saw the election numbers as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he told a news conference.\n\nModi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's during his first two terms in office, and he turned the parliamentary election into one that more resembled a presidential-style campaign, with the BJP relying on the leader's brand.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nUnder Modi's government, critics say India's democracy has come under increasing strain with strong-arm tactics used to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nEconomic discontent has also simmered under Modi. While stock markets have reached record-highs, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With Modi at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" he repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\n\"These issues have resonated and made a dent,\" added Aiyar, the public policy scholar.", "source": {"uri": "delcotimes.com", {"uri": "2024-06-377826522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:43:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:43:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T02:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/7893efecc83fa8225a611f174e6420ee/india-begins-counting-votes-marathon-election-expected", "title": "India begins counting votes in marathon election expected to bring Prime Minister Modi a third term", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India on Tuesday began counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout was around 66% on average across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8160420258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "04:57:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T04:57:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T04:57:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.adaderana.lk/news.php?nid=99648", "title": "India begins counting votes in marathon election expected to bring Prime Minister Modi a third term", "body": "India began counting more than 640 million votes Tuesday in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe six-week election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout was around 66% on average across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson.\n\n\"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign.\n\nThe result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness.\n\nMeanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. {"uri": "8160765548", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:06:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:06:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:06:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/national-international/india-counts-votes-from-a-mega-election-seen-as-a-referendum-on-modi/3454223/", "title": "India counts votes in world's biggest elections", "body": "India started counting votes Tuesday from its staggered, six-week election that was seen as a referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decade in power and was expected to give him a third term in office.\n\nEarly leads showed fewer seats for Modi's governing Bharatiya Janata Party than expected. BJP is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties were leading in 283 constituencies according to an early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which was leading in 232 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million people -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to vote and turnout averaged 66%, according to official data. The tallying at counting centers in 543 constituencies could stretch well into the evening before final results are announced, though substantial leads are likely to emerge earlier.\n\nIndia's vote is the latest in an unusually busy stretch of elections around the world that are challenging the status quo.\n\nIf the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nSome four hours into the counting, early leads reported by the Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead of the main opposition Congress party.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting was to go on throughout the day and early figures were expected to change.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 7%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nTemperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing evaporative coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bharatiya Janata Party"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Narendra Modi"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electoral_district", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Electoral district"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "India"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-06-378071076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:55:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:55:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T07:49:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/narendra-modi-set-clinch-third-074918947.html", "title": "Narendra Modi set to clinch third five-year term in India election", "body": "Indian prime minister Narendra Modi is on course to clinch a third five-year term at the helm of the world's largest population.\n\nMore than 640 million votes have been cast in the general election over the past six weeks with a final result set to be declared on Tuesday.\n\nIf 73-year-old Mr Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nSome three hours into the counting, early leads reported by the Election Commission showed Mr Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead of the main opposition Congress party.\n\nThe preliminary figures showed the BJP ahead in 239 constituencies out of 542 and winning one uncontested race. Congress was leading in 96 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting was to go on throughout the day and early figures were expected to change.\n\nExit polls on Saturday projected a broad win for Mr Modi's National Democratic Alliance group over an opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66 per cent turnout across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nTemperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing evaporative coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Mr Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14 per cent of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nMr Modi's critics say the country's democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047\", Mr Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Mr Modi ramped up polarising rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energise his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA) led by the Congress party, has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Mr Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019 when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8160536585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:31:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/04/modis-party-has-comfortable-lead-over-main-rival-in-early-vote-counting-from-indias-election/", "title": "Modi's party has comfortable lead over main rival in early vote counting from India's election - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Krutika Pathi And Sheikh Saaliq, The Associated Press on June 4, 2024.\n\nPolice officers stand guard at a vote counting centre ahead of the counting for Indian parliamentary elections in Mumbai, India, Monday, June 3, 2024. India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. (AP Photo/Rafiq Maqbool)NEW DELHI (AP) - India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday. If the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister. Some three hours into the counting, early leads reported by the Election Commission showed Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead of the main opposition Congress party. The preliminary figures showed the BJP ahead in 239 constituencies out of 542 and winning one uncontested race. Congress was leading in 96 constituencies. The Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting was to go on throughout the day and early figures were expected to change. Exit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a broad win for Modi's National Democratic Alliance group over an opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi. Some 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66% turnout across the seven phases, according to official data. Extreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\"\u009d he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\u009d Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing evaporative coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters. On Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face. In his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections. \"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\"\u009d said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest. But a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population. India's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom. The country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing. As polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\"\u009d highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\"\u009d Modi repeated in rally after rally. But the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters. His opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality. But the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this. Another victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats. ______ AP reporter David Rising contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com",
