{"uri": "8160878352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:14:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:14:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:13:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/business/indian-markets-close-sharply-down-as-early-count-shows-modis-party-faces-tighter-than-expected/article_dd265d3c-e78c-581e-9e8a-72e4650fd07d.html", "title": "Indian markets close sharply down as early count shows Modi's party faces tighter than expected race", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Indian markets closed sharply down Tuesday as early counting showed that Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party faced a tighter than expected race.\n\nIndia's benchmark stock indices, the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex, had hit new highs at the close of day Monday but dropped sharply Tuesday as the early vote figures started to come in.\n\nThey recovered slightly to each close down more than 5%.\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople. Critics have said India has become more unequal.\n\nEven if Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party does not secure a parliamentary majority on its own, early counts reported by India's Election Commission showed his coalition including smaller parties leading in a majority of seats.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was set to take all day. Modi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term -- even as the race tightened and the early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures were expected to change.\n\nThe \"Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 7%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAssociated Press writer David Rising contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": {"uri": "8160289487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:46:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:46:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T02:45:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/03/india-begins-counting-votes-in-marathon-election-expected-to-bring-prime-minister-modi-a-third-term/", "title": "India begins counting votes in marathon election expected to bring Prime Minister Modi a third term - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Krutika Pathi And Sheikh Saaliq, The Associated Press on June 3, 2024.\n\nPolice officers stand guard at a vote counting centre ahead of the counting for Indian parliamentary elections in Mumbai, India, Monday, June 3, 2024. India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. (AP Photo/Rafiq Maqbool)NEW DELHI (AP) - India on Tuesday began counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. The 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister. Exit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi. Indian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results. Nearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout was around 66% on average across the seven phases, according to official data. The tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India. But leads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed. In his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections. \"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\"\u009d said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest. But a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population. India's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom. The country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing. As polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\"\u009d highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\"\u009d Modi repeated in rally after rally. But the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters. His opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality. But the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this. Another victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-377802140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "01:56:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T01:56:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T00:43:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/03/indias-marathon-election-enters-final-stage-of-vote-counting-with-modi-widely-tipped-for-third-term/", "title": "India's marathon election enters final stage of vote counting with Modi widely tipped for third term", "body": "Police officers stand guard at a vote counting centre ahead of the counting for Indian parliamentary elections in Mumbai, India, Monday, June 3, 2024. India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime [...]\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout averaged 66% across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will emerge earlier and indicate where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378618604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:48:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:48:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T00:43:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/2024/06/03/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-indias-general-election/", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "By KRUTIKA PATHI and SHEIKH SAALIQ (Associated Press)\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lackluster performance from his own party as it faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time. \"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own - but the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it might not secure a majority on its own, according to the ongoing vote count -- but the prime minister was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi has to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. Despite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 year remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, both sides claimed they had won some sort of victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Gandhi said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "oneidadispatch.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8160927367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:43:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:43:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:43:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/national/24364561.india-election-modis-coalition-leads-opposition-stiffer-expected/", "title": "India election: Modi's coalition leads but opposition is stiffer than expected", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition is leading in a majority of seats in India's general election, according to early figures.\n\nHowever, Mr Modi's coalition faces a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarising politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise is likely to take all day. Mr Modi is still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term - even as the race tightens and the early count showed his party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nMr Modi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures are expected to change.\n\n\"(The) Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down on Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices - the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than 5%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45C in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Mr Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Mr Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Mr Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Mr Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Mr Modi ramped up polarising rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energise his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition India alliance has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they have been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. {"uri": "8161410567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:48:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:48:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:47:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae:443/news/2024/06/04/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-india-general-election", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Modi said that his National Democratic Alliance (NDA) will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own - but the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Rahul said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices - the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than 5%.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.", "source": {"uri": "gulftoday.ae", {"uri": "8160314871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:13:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:13:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:12:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-lok-sabha-elections-2024-counting-of-votes-begins-543-constituencies-pm-narendra-modi-rahul-gandhi-bjp-nda-3091895", "title": "Lok Sabha Elections 2024: Counting of votes begins across 543 constituencies, PM Modi tipped to return for third term", "body": "Lok Sabha Elections' vote counting has begun at 8am on Tuesday, June 4\n\nIndia on Tuesday begun counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.Exit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results. Nearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout averaged 66% across the seven phases, according to official data. The tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India. But leads will emerge earlier and indicate where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections. \"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population. India's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing. As polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally. But the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality. But the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nExcept for the headline, this story has not been edited by DNA staff and is published from AP", {"uri": "8161311288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:42:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:42:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:41:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/india-election-modi-says-his-coalition-is-on-the-path-to-a-third-straight-term-calling-it-a-historical-feat-1.6912525", "title": "India election: Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term, calling it a 'historical feat'", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term in India's election, calling it a \"historical feat.\"\n\nHis coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome eight hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 231 constituencies and had won 13, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 93 constituencies and had won four.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 277 constituencies and won 15, according to the early count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 220 constituencies and had won five.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen -- people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nA worker carries a banner of Bharatiya Janta party featuring Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be put up outside party headquarters in New Delhi, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Dinesh Joshi)\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nA roadside fruit juice seller watches the election results on his mobile phone in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Bikas Das)\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_government", Mr Modi is still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term - even as the race tightens and the early count showed his party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nMr Modi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures are expected to change.\n\n\"(The) Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down on Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices - the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than 5%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45C in some parts of the country. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Mr Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Mr Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Mr Modi ramped up polarising rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energise his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition India alliance has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics", "wgt": 19}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Campaigns_and_Elections", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Campaigns and Elections", "wgt": "wgt": 17}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 86}], "image": "https://d3gvyx4eg3tne0.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Img38196526.jpg", "originalArticle": null, {"uri": "2024-06-378600913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:18:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-india-s-general-election/article_1cbafe49-26f9-550c-a343-0145765ed575.html", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Faces of Trinamool Congress Party supporters smeared with green colour celebrate the election results in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party showed a comfortable lead Tuesday, according to early figures reported by India's Election Commission, but was facing a stronger challenge from the opposition than had been expected.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lackluster performance from his own party as it faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time. \"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own - but the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it might not secure a majority on its own, according to the ongoing vote count -- but the prime minister was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi has to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. Despite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 year remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, both sides claimed they had won some sort of victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Gandhi said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8161179026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:18:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:18:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:17:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/490671/Modi-expected-to-retain-power-but-early-India-count-suggests-it-won-t-be-the-landslide-he-hoped-for", "title": "Modi expected to retain power but early India count suggests it won't be the landslide he hoped for - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press FILE - Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has sandalwood paste and vermilion applied on his forehead during the inauguration of Kashi Vishwanath Dham Corridor, a promenade that connects the Ganges River with the centuries-old temple dedicated to Hindu god Shiva in Varanasi, India, Dec. 13, 2021. India began counting more than 640 million votes Tuesday in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. (AP Photo/Rajesh Kumar Singh, File)\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as an ongoing count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome 10 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 196 constituencies and had won 45, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 236 constituencies and won 50, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 211 constituencies and had won 19.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much
