{"uri": "8161210454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:38:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:38:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:37:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/world/indian-opposition-calls-its-strong-election-showing-a-moral-and-political-loss-for-modi/article_aa683cbe-0234-51ba-ac1a-d2b90c7e956a.html", "title": "Indian opposition calls its strong election showing a 'moral and political loss' for Modi", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's main opposition Congress party has called its alliance's strong showing a \"win for democracy\" and a \"moral and political loss\" for Prime Minister Narendra Modi.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term and a partial count showed his coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election. But his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference, Congress party president Mallikarjun Kharge pledged a vigorous opposition.\n\n\"We will continue to fight for the country's development, for the constitution, for the benefit of the people,\" Kharge said.\n\nRahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign, said the preliminary vote figures were a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise -- even as an ongoing count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome 10 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 196 constituencies and had won 45, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 236 constituencies and won 50, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 211 constituencies and had won 19.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": During the grueling, multiphase election, candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat. The election, whose results are to be announced Tuesday, is considered one of the most consequential in India's history, the AP reports. If Modi wins, he'll be only the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls by major television news channels projected Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies were leading over the broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party. Most exit polls projected BJP and its allies could win more than 350 seats out of 543 -- far ahead of the 272 seats needed to form the next government. The polls are released by various news agencies, but analysts caution that they have often been wrong before and are not impartial, per the BBC. Modi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But it turned increasingly shrill as Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of the nation's 1.4 billion people.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest, per the AP. At the same time, his rule has included brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering, and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state. His party began to face stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.", "source": {"uri": "newser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newser"}, {"uri": "8161278255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:19:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/7893efecc83fa8225a611f174e6420ee/modi-says-his-coalition-path-third-straight-term-calling", "title": "Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term, calling it a 'historical feat'", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term in India's election, calling it a \"historical feat.\"\n\nHis coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nHis Hindu nationalist party appeared unlikely to secure a majority on its own, according to an ongoing count showed, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory -- but Modi was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome 10 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 196 constituencies and had won 45, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 236 constituencies and won 50, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 211 constituencies and had won 19.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nAt a news conference, the Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge said the alliance's strong showing was a \"win for democracy\" and a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\nGandhi added that the figures were a message from the people: \"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India.\"\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists David Rising in New Delhi and Rafiq Maqbool in Mumbai, India, contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", If Prime Minister Narendra Modi wins, he'll be the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nMost poll surveys show Modi and his nationalist BJP party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party.\n\nModi's campaign began on a platform of economic progress, with vows to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. {"uri": "8156188914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-01", "time": "06:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-01T06:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-01T06:26:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/01/world/india-election-modi/", "title": "Voting begins in the last round of India's election, a referendum on Modi's decade in power - The Boston Globe", "body": "Most polls show Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party leading over the broad opposition alliance that's challenging them, led by the Congress party. The votes will be counted Tuesday, with results expected by the end of the day.\n\nModi's campaign, vying for a third-straight term, began on a platform of economic progress. He has promised to uplift the poor and turn India into a developed nation by 2047. But the campaign has turned increasingly shrill in recent weeks as he escalated polarizing rhetoric in back-to-back incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority, who make up 14% of India's 1.4 billion people.\n\nAfter ending campaigning on Thursday, Modi went to meditate at a memorial site honoring a famous Hindu saint who is believed to have attained enlightenment there.\n\nWhen the election kicked off in April, Modi and his BJP were widely expected to clinch another term.\n\nSince first coming to power in 2014, Modi has enjoyed immense popularity. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nAt the same time, his rule has seen brazen attacks and hate speech against minorities, particularly Muslims. India's democracy, his critics say, is faltering and Modi has increasingly blurred the line between religion and state.\n\nBut as the campaign ground on, his party has faced stiff resistance from the opposition alliance and its main face, Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party. They have attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics and are hoping to benefit from growing economic discontent.\n\nPre-poll surveys showed that voters were increasingly worried about unemployment, the rise in food prices and an overall sentiment that only a small portion of Indians have benefitted despite brisk economic growth under Modi, making the contest appear closer than initially anticipated.\n\nIn Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal, voters lined up outside polling stations early Saturday morning to avoid the scorching heat, with temperatures expected to reach 34 degrees Celsius (93.2 Fahrenheit). Modi is challenged there by the state's chief minister, Mamata Banerjee, who heads the regional Trinamool Congress party.\n\n\"There is a crunch for jobs now in the present market. I will vote for the government that can uplift jobs. And I hope those who cannot get jobs, they will get jobs,\" said Ankit Samaddar.\n\nIn this election, Modi's BJP -- which controls much of India's Hindi-speaking northern and central parts -- sought to expand their influence by making inroads into the country's eastern and southern states, where regional parties hold greater sway.\n\nThe BJP also banked on consolidating votes among the Hindu majority, who make up 80% of the population, after Modi opened a long-demanded Hindu temple on the site of a razed mosque in January. Many saw it as the unofficial start of his campaign, but analysts said the excitement over the temple may not be enough to yield votes.\n\nInstead, Modi ramped up anti-Muslim rhetoric after voter turnout dipped slightly below 2019 figures in the first few rounds of the 2024 polls.\n\nThis was seen as a tactic to energize his core Hindu voter base. But analysts say it also reflected the lack of any big-ticket national issue to help Modi propel his BJP to electoral victory, as he has done previously.\n\nIn 2014, Modi's status as a political outsider cracking down on deep-rooted corruption won over voters disillusioned with decades of dynastic politics. And in 2019, he swept the polls on a wave of nationalism after his government launched airstrikes into rival Pakistan in response to a suicide bombing in Kashmir that killed 40 Indian soldiers.\n\nBut things are different this time, analysts say, giving Modi's political challengers a potential boost.\n\n\"The opposition somehow managed to derail his plan by setting the narrative to local issues, like unemployment and the economy. This election, people are voting keeping various issues in mind,\" said Rasheed Kidwai, a political analyst.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston {"uri": "8161381536", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:29:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:29:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:27:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/modi-expected-to-get-3rd-term-but-partial-india-count-suggests-narrower-win-that-represents-setback-1.6912525", "title": "Modi expected to get 3rd term but partial India count suggests narrower win that represents setback", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it might not secure a majority on its own, according to the ongoing vote count -- but the prime minister was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi has to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. Despite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 year remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, both sides claimed they had won some sort of victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nA worker carries a banner of Bharatiya Janta party featuring Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be put up outside party headquarters in New Delhi, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Dinesh Joshi)\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Gandhi said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nA roadside fruit juice seller watches the election results on his mobile phone in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Bikas Das)\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen -- people haven't supported the BJP so much {"uri": "8161214746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:41:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:41:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:40:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/04/modi-expected-to-retain-power-but-early-india-count-suggests-hell-need-coalition/", "title": "Modi expected to retain power but early India count suggests he'll need coalition", "body": "Election officials carry sealed electronic voting machines Tuesday at a counting center in Mumbai, India. Rafiq Maqbool/Associated Press\n\nNEW DELHI -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise - even as an ongoing count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own, despite pre-election hopes of a landslide victory.\n\nIf that trend holds, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old leader, who has never been in a position where he has needed to rely on his coalition partners to govern.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was set to take all day, and early figures could change.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSome 10 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 196 constituencies and had won 45, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 83 constituencies and had won 15.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose members led in 236 constituencies and won 50, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 211 constituencies and had won 19.\n\nA woman shows her index fingers marked with an indelible ink as she poses for a photograph next to a cutout portrait of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi after casting her vote Saturday in the seventh and final phase of India's national elections, in Varanasi, India. Rajesh Kumar Singh/Associated Press\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices - the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex - both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nA polling official tick marks on a chart after the first round of counting of votes Tuesday at a counting center in New Delhi, India. Manish Swarup/Associated Press\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen - people haven't supported the BJP so much this time.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", {"uri": "8160920439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:40:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:40:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:38:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.bworldonline.com/world/2024/06/04/599518/indias-modi-eyes-biggest-win-yet-as-votes-are-counted-in-giant-election/", "title": "India's Modi eyes biggest win yet as votes are counted in giant election - BusinessWorld Online", "body": "NEW DELHI -- India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equaling third consecutive term in office as the counting of 642 million votes in the world's largest election began on Tuesday.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Mr. Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India.\n\nHowever, if Mr. Modi's victory is confirmed, his Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nIndia stock futures edged higher and the rupee was steady before the count began at 8:00 a.m. (0230 GMT) on Tuesday. The NIFTY 50 index futures rose 0.21% in early trade, according to NSE International Exchange data, and was looking at another record high open.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favor.\n\nMr. Modi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee.\"\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favoring India's 200 million Muslims -- a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters. -- {"uri": "2024-06-378229326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:11:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:11:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:07:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/business/indian-markets-close-sharply-down-as-early-count-shows-modis-party-faces-tighter-than-expected/article_b7594cbd-eebe-5ab2-b1a9-b40a31ea1836.html", "title": "Indian markets close sharply down as early count shows Modi's party faces tighter than expected race", "body": "Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) party supporters cheer as they follow proceedings of the vote counting at their party office in Chennai, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. India was counting more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to give Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term when the final result is declared later Tuesday.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Indian markets closed sharply down Tuesday as early counting showed that Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party faced a tighter than expected race.\n\nIndia's benchmark stock indices, the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex, had hit new highs at the close of day Monday but dropped sharply Tuesday as the early vote figures started to come in.\n\nThey recovered slightly to each close down more than 5%.\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople. Critics have said India has become more unequal.\n\nEven if Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party does not secure a parliamentary majority on its own, early counts reported by India's Election Commission showed his coalition including smaller parties leading in a majority of seats.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW DELHI (AP) -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was set to take all day. Modi was still widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term -- even as the race tightened and the early count showed his Hindu nationalist party might not secure a majority on its own.\n\nIf Modi wins, it would cement the 73-year-old as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nSome seven hours into counting, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two, including one uncontested, of 543 parliamentary seats. The main opposition Congress party led in 99 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties led in 287 constituencies, according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 230 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, and early figures were expected to change.\n\nThe \"Congress party and other opposition parties have showed tremendous resilience. To have a stronger opposition augers very well for India's democracy that has taken a hit during Modi's 10-year rule,\" said political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 7%.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nBJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAssociated Press writer David Rising contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "yakimaherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yakima Herald-Republic"}, {"uri": "8161408745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:47:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:47:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:46:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-india-s-general-election-1.6912525", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lackluster performance from his own party as it faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nModi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time. \"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own -- but the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\n----\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\n----\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to partial figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected after it pushed back against the leader's mixed economic record and polarizing politics.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it might not secure a majority on its own, according to the ongoing vote count -- but the prime minister was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi has to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. Despite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he's instituted over the last 10 year remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, both sides claimed they had won some sort of victory.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in the NDA, for a third consecutive time,\" Modi wrote on social media platform X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance that his party heads. \"This is a historical feat in India's history.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the main opposition Congress party said the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world. His critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and while the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 5%.\n\nA worker carries a banner of Bharatiya Janta party featuring Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be put up outside party headquarters in New Delhi, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Dinesh Joshi)\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said. \"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls. While temperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday, election officials and political parties still hauled in large quantities of water and installed outdoor air coolers for people waiting for results.\n\nOutside BJP party headquarters in New Delhi, supporters banged drums and bells as the counting was underway. Earlier, party workers performed a Hindu ritual.\n\nMeanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Rahul Gandhi, the face of the party's campaign.\n\nSpeaking at the press conference with party president Kharge, Gandhi said he saw the figures as a message from the people.\n\n\"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India,\" he said.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nA roadside fruit juice seller watches the election results on his mobile phone in Kolkata, India, Tuesday, June 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Bikas Das)\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the boom.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted Muslims, who make up 14% of the population, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics, and campaigned on issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nIn the financial capital of Mumbai, Mangesh Mahadeshwar was one of many surprised by how the election was playing out.\n\n\"Yesterday we thought that the BJP would get more than 400 seats,\" said 52-year-old who was keeping an eye on the results at the restaurant where he works. \"Today it seems like that won't happen -- people haven't supported the BJP so much {"uri": "2024-06-377769117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "00:49:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T00:49:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-03/indias-marathon-election-enters-final-stage-of-vote-counting-with-modi-widely-tipped-for-third-term", "title": "India's Marathon Election Enters Final Stage of Vote Counting With Modi Widely Tipped for Third Term", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nThe 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout averaged 66% across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will emerge earlier and indicate where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\" highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\" Modi repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters.\n\nHis opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-06-378639305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:07:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:07:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:56:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/narendra-modi-claims-victory-alliance-155647743.html", "title": "Narendra Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "PRIME Minister Narendra Modi has claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lacklustre performance from his own party.\n\nHe faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which rejected the leader's mixed economic record and polarising politics.\n\nModi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time. \"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own.\n\nBut the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Modi, 73, does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for him. He had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nREAD MORE: Rachel Reeves denies Anas Sarwar 'blew apart' her fiscal rules in debate\n\nDespite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he has instituted over the last 10 years remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, the opposition claimed they had also won a victory of sorts, with the main opposition Congress party saying the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party president Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world.\n\nHis critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nREAD MORE: John Swinney and Anas Sarwar clash in TV debate over Labour's economy plans\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's election commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe election commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats.\n\nREAD MORE: Nigel Farage hit with milkshake as he launches election campaign\n\nIndian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices, the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex, both down by more than 5%.\n\nIf Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term, after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation\", said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Programme at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign.\n\nThe result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nThe country's democracy, his critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent.\n\nThe government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8160505375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "06:09:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T06:09:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:08:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/518642/modi-s-alliance-dominates-early-in-india-election-vote-count-but-opposition-also-gains", "title": "Modi's alliance dominates early in India election vote count, but opposition also gains", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance raced to a majority in early vote counting trends in the general election on Tuesday, but the numbers were well short of the landslide predicted in exit polls, TV channels showed.\n\nThe early see-saw trends unnerved markets with stocks falling steeply. The NIFTY 50 and the S&P BSE Sensex were both down over 2 percent at 0500 GMT.\n\nThe rupee also fell against the dollar and benchmark bond yields were up.\n\nThe markets had soared on Monday after exit polls on 1 June projected Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would register a big victory, with its National Democratic Alliance (NDA) seen getting a two-thirds majority and more.\n\nAt 0430 GMT, TV channels showed the NDA was ahead in nearly 300 of the 543 elective seats in parliament, a simple majority, in early counting. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was leading in over 200 seats, higher than expected.\n\nOnly about 10 percent - 15 percent of the total votes had been counted at the time, TV channels said.\n\nBJP alone accounted for nearly 250 of the seats in which the NDA was leading, compared to the 303 it won in 2019. Trends also showed Modi leading first, then trailing and leading again in his seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi.\n\nThe first votes counted were postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty.\n\nThis year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots.\n\n\"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll that began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50- Celsius in some parts.\n\nMore than 66 percent of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, was seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party, which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's BJP to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes.
