{"uri": "8161401975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:43:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:43:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:41:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/04/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-indias-general-election/", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Narendra Modi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lacklustre performance from his own party.\n\nHe faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which rejected the leader's mixed economic record and polarising politics.\n\nMr Modi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own.\n\nBut the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Mr Modi, 73, does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for him. He had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nDespite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he has instituted over the last 10 years remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, the opposition claimed they had also won a victory of sorts, with the main opposition Congress party saying the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party president Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world.\n\nHis critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's election commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Mr Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe election commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats.\n\nIndian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices, the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex, both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said.\n\n\"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term, after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation\", said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program,e at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Mr Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Mr Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign.\n\nThe result is that the BJP relies more and more on Mr Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nThe country's democracy, his critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent.\n\nThe government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8160470225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:41:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:41:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:39:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.thejakartapost.com/world/2024/06/04/modis-alliance-dominates-early-in-india-election-vote-count-but-opposition-also-gains.html", "title": "Modi's alliance dominates early in India election vote count, but opposition also gains - Asia & Pacific - The Jakarta Post", "body": "ndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance raced to a majority in early vote counting trends in the general election on Tuesday, but the numbers were well short of the landslide predicted in exit polls, TV channels showed.\n\nThe early see-saw trends unnerved markets with stocks falling steeply. The NIFTY and the BSE were both down over 2 percent.\n\nThe rupee also fell against the dollar and benchmark bond yields were up.\n\nThe markets had soared on Monday after exit polls on June 1 projected Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would register a big victory, with its National Democratic Alliance (NDA) seen getting a two-thirds majority and more.\n\nEarlier, TV channels showed the NDA was ahead in nearly 300 of the 543 elective seats in parliament, a simple majority, in early counting. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was leading in over 200 seats, higher than expected.\n\nOnly about 10 percent-15 percent of the total votes had been counted at the time, TV channels said.\n\nBJP alone accounted for nearly 250 of the seats in which the NDA was leading, compared to the 303 it won in 2019. Trends also showed Modi leading first, then trailing and leading again in his seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi.\n\nThe first votes counted were postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty.\n\nThis year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots.\n\n\"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out.\n\nVitriolic campaign\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll that began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius in some parts.\n\nMore than 66 percent of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favor.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party, which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favoring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's BJP to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance denied it favored Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. {"uri": "8160454356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:27:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:27:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:26:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/asia-pacific/2024/06/04/india-election-modi-expected-to-win-third-term-as-count-of-640m-votes-under-way/", "title": "India election: Modi expected to win third term as count of 640m votes under way", "body": "Exit polls project a comfortable victory for prime minister's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies\n\nIndia has started counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise that is widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi for a third term.\n\nThe six-week-long election was seen as a referendum on the Mr Modi (73), who would be the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Mr Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nAccording to official data, nearly 970 million people, more than 10 per cent of the world's population, were eligible to vote, with an average turnout of around 66 per cent across the seven phases.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centres in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could continue into Tuesday evening before the Election Commission of India declares a final result.\n\nLeads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, his popularity outstripping that of his party and turning a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14 per cent of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become unequal under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the economic boom.\n\nMr Modi's critics say the country's democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly used strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media, and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements his party says have reduced poverty.\n\nHis opposition, the India alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics.\n\nThe alliance hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation, and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of more than a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over its effectiveness.\n\nThe alliance has also claimed it has been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against its leaders by federal agencies it says are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Mr Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow the BJP's thumping win in 2019, winning 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats. - AP", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-378218809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:03:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:03:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:03:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://jakartaglobe.id/news/modis-party-well-ahead-in-indian-elections-but-opposition-stiffer-than-expected", "title": "Modi's Party Well Ahead in Indian Elections But Opposition Stiffer Than Expected", "body": "New Delhi. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party showed a comfortable lead Tuesday, according to early figures reported by India's Election Commission, but was facing a stronger challenge from the opposition than had been expected.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over the past six weeks in the world's largest democratic exercise was expected to take all day, with Modi widely expected to be elected to a third five-year term when the final result is declared.\n\nIf the 73-year-old Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nSome four hours into the counting, early leads reported by the Election Commission showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead of the main opposition Congress party.\n\nThe preliminary figures showed the BJP ahead in 240 constituencies out of 542 and winning one uncontested race. Congress was leading in 94 constituencies.\n\nModi's National Democratic Alliance group was leading in 287 constituencies, while the opposition INDIA alliance, led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi was leading in 225.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting was to go on throughout the day and early figures were expected to change.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats. Indian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices -- the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex -- both down by more than 7 percent.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with an average 66 percent turnout across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nExtreme heat struck India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. The chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. \"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nTemperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing evaporative coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and party headquarters.\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual shortly after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14 percent of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nThe country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and said democracy is flourishing. Tags:", "source": {"uri": "jakartaglobe.id", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jakarta Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress", "type": "org", {"uri": "8161411579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:49:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:49:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/06/04/modi-claims-victory-for-his-alliance-in-indias-general-election/", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday in India's general election, despite a lacklustre performance from his own party.\n\nHe faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which rejected the leader's mixed economic record and polarising politics.\n\nMr Modi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own.\n\nBut the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Mr Modi, 73, does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for him. He had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nDespite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he has instituted over the last 10 years remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, the opposition claimed they had also won a victory of sorts, with the main opposition Congress party saying the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world.\n\nHis critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's election commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe election commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats.\n\nIndian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices, the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex, both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said.\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term, after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation\", said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program,e at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Mr Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Mr Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign.\n\nThe result is that the BJP relies more and more on Mr Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nThe country's democracy, his critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent.\n\nThe government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefiting from the boom.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8160322275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:19:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://kathmandupost.com/world/2024/06/04/india-s-modi-eyes-biggest-win-yet-as-votes-are-counted-in-giant-election", "title": "India's Modi eyes biggest win yet as votes are counted in giant election", "body": "India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi greets supporters during a roadshow, ahead of the general elections, in Ghaziabad, India, April 6, 2024. Reuters\n\nIndia's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equalling third consecutive term in office as the counting of 642 million votes in the world's largest election began on Tuesday.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working-age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nIndia stock futures edged higher and the rupee was steady before the count began at 8:00am (0230 GMT) on Tuesday. The NIFTY 50 index futures rose 0.21% in early trade, according to NSE International Exchange data, and was looking at another record high open.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters.", {"uri": "8161618468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "18:23:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T18:23:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T18:22:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.nigeriasun.com/news/274395457/modi-set-to-win-narrow-majority-but-his-partys-numbers-slide", "title": "Modi set to win narrow majority, but his party's numbers slide", "body": "NEW DELHI - An alliance led by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is on course to win a small majority in parliament, but a strong challenge from the opposition significantly reduces his party's numbers, reflecting his waning popularity after a decade in office.\n\nModi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, or BJP, along with its allies, was headed to secure some 290 seats out of the 543 elected seats in the lower house of parliament.\n\nIn a post on X, Modi said that \"people have placed their faith in NDA, for a third consecutive time! This is a historical feat in India's history.\" The NDA is the National Democratic Alliance, which is led by the BJP.\n\nHe assured people \"that we will continue the good work done in the last decade to keep fulfilling the aspirations of people.\" He displayed a victory sign at BJP headquarters Tuesday evening.\n\nHowever, in a massive setback to the Indian leader, who has ruled the country with a decisive mandate over the past decade, the BJP was not likely to secure a clear majority on its own. The party was winning or ahead with about 240 seats - well short of the 272 seats needed for a majority - in votes counted until Tuesday evening. That is significantly lower than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nAnalysts say the BJP's weaker-than-expected performance showed Modi's charisma has waned. The Indian leader, who critics call polarizing and divisive, ran a presidential-style campaign, with the party depending heavily on him to pull in votes. But he will now have to depend on his allies to form the next government.\n\nPolitical analyst Nilanjan Mukhopadhyay said, \"Modi has never worked with coalition partners in the past and has always been a leader with his own mind. But without a clear majority for his own party, he will have to be a much more subdued prime minister and work with his allies.\"\n\nWhile Modi may not have won the landslide mandate his party expected and exit polls forecast, he will be only the second prime minister in India - after the country's first, Jawaharlal Nehru - to win a third term in office.\n\nModi, who is seen as a strong leader, has built his popularity on a raft of welfare programs and a strident brand of Hindu nationalism in the majority-Hindu country. But analysts say rising unemployment, especially among young people, and high inflation in a country where millions are still poor, cut into his support.\n\n\"I did not see any wave for Modi on the ground,\" said political analyst Neerja Chowdhury. \"Also, the opposition fought well. This time, they did not give up. There was a spiritedness in their campaign.\"\n\nSupporters greet Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi as he arrives at Bharatiya Janata Party headquarters in New Delhi on June 4, 2024.\n\nThe BJP suffered its biggest losses in Uttar Pradesh, a populous, politically crucial state where vote counting showed the party trailing in about half the 80 parliamentary seats. The most significant defeat the party suffered was in Faizabad, a constituency where in January Modi inaugurated a huge temple in honor of Hindu god Rama. Hailed by many Hindus, it was expected to boost Modi's support.\n\nAn opposition alliance of about two dozen parties led by the Congress Party mounted a united challenge to the BJP and got a huge boost. The alliance, which ran on a platform of reducing wealth inequality and upholding democratic institutions, was heading for victory in around 220 seats - nearly double its present tally of 119 in parliament.\n\nThe opposition emphasized joblessness and accused Modi of undermining the secular fabric of the country, targeting his political opponents and being intolerant of dissent.\n\n\"It shows that India has become a much more competitive democracy. It also shows that people reacted against a slide into a kind of authoritarian regime,\" Mukhopadhyay said.\n\nThe results were also good news for the Congress Party, once India's dominant party, which suffered crushing defeats in two previous elections. It is on course to nearly double its numbers to about 100 seats, which analysts say could revive the party.\n\nThe Congress Party called the election a win for democracy and a mandate against Modi.\n\n\"Our fight was not against a political party but a fight to save the constitution,\" party leader Rahul Gandhi said.\n\n\"The country has unanimously and clearly stated that we do not want Narendra Modi and [Minister of Home Affairs] Amit Shah to be involved in running the country,\" Gandhi said.\n\nOther opposition leaders said Modi lost his credibility.\n\nSome positive news for BJP\n\nAlthough the BJP lost ground, there was some good news for the party. It was on course to win in the eastern Odisha state, formerly Orissa, and was also performing well in some southern states. The victories will help the BJP build its credentials as a pan-Indian party - for decades, it drew its maximum support from populous states of the north and west where its Hindu nationalist agenda struck a chord.\n\nOn the streets, reactions were mixed. In the business hub of Gurugram, young people who see Modi as a strong leader who has improved India's economy say they will be happy to see him lead the country for a third term.\n\n\"Since Modi has come, there has been good development in the country. He is supportive of the young generation,\" said Varun Singh, an undergraduate student.\n\nOthers welcomed the election results for a different reason.\n\n\"It is good that we will have a strong opposition because it is good for democracy to have checks and balances,\" said New Delhi resident Purnima Mehta.\n\nIndia's stock markets dropped 5.74% as news that the elections had failed to deliver a clear mandate to the BJP, seen as a business-friendly party that planned to bring in more reforms.\n\nSome 642 million people, making up about 66% of registered voters, cast ballots in the world's biggest election that stretched over six weeks in searing heat.", "source": {"uri": "nigeriasun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Nigeria Sun"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161413760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:50:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:50:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41409326.html", "title": "Modi claims victory for his alliance in India's general election", "body": "He faced a stronger than expected challenge from the opposition, which rejected the leader's mixed economic record and polarising politics.\n\nMr Modi said that his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" he said, speaking at his party headquarters.\n\nFor the first time since Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party swept to power in 2014, it appeared unlikely that it would secure a majority on its own.\n\nBut the prime minister's coalition was still expected to be elected to a third five-year term in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nIf Mr Modi, 73, does have to rely on coalition support to govern, it would be a stunning blow for him. He had hoped for a landslide victory.\n\nDespite the setback, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he has instituted over the last 10 years remain locked in place.\n\nIn the face of surprising numbers, the opposition claimed they had also won a victory of sorts, with the main opposition Congress party saying the election had been a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi.\n\n\"This is public's victory and a win for democracy,\" Congress party president Mallikarjun Kharge told reporters.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, bringing Hindu nationalism, once a fringe ideology in India, into the mainstream while leaving the country deeply divided.\n\nHis supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world.\n\nHis critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance and the economy, the world's fifth-largest and one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of more than 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to last into the night.\n\nSome 12 hours into counting, partial tallies reported by India's election commission showed Modi's BJP was ahead in 114 constituencies and had won 126 of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and had won 54.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats, while they secured 282 in 2014 when Mr Modi first came to power.\n\nThe BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, according to the partial count. The Congress party is part of the India alliance, which led in 131 constituencies and had won 99.\n\nThe election commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats.\n\nIndian markets, which had hit an all-time high on Monday, closed sharply down Tuesday, with benchmark stock indices, the Nifty 50 and the BSE Sensex, both down by more than 5%.\n\nFor Payal, a resident of the northern city of Lucknow who uses only one name, the election was about the economy and India's vast number of people living in poverty.\n\n\"People are suffering, there are no jobs, people are in such a state that their kids are compelled to make and sell tea on the roadside,\" Payal said.\n\n\"This is a big deal for us. If we don't wake up now, when will we?\"\n\nIf Mr Modi wins, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term, after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nBut if his BJP is forced to form a coalition, the party would likely \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation\", said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program,e at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" he added.\n\nBefore Mr Modi came to power, India had coalition governments for 30 years. His BJP has always had a majority on its own while still governing in a coalition.\n\nOver 10 years in power, Mr Modi's popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembled a presidential-style campaign.\n\nThe result is that the BJP relies more and more on Mr Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections.\n\nThe country's democracy, his critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent.\n\nThe government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing.\n\nAnd economic discontent has simmered under Mr Modi. {"uri": "8160437424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:14:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:14:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:12:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2960596-modis-alliance-leads-early-vote-counting-markets-wobble", "title": "Modi's Alliance Leads Early Vote Counting, Markets Wobble | Politics", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance leads early vote counts, but results fall short of exit poll predictions. Early trends cause market declines, with significant drops in NIFTY 50 and S&P BSE Sensex. The election, marked by a vitriolic campaign, sees BJP's leading, but results are still unfolding.\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance raced to a majority in early vote counting trends in the general election on Tuesday, but the numbers were well short of the landslide predicted in exit polls, TV channels showed.\n\nThe early see-saw trends unnerved markets with stocks falling steeply. The NIFTY 50 and the S&P BSE Sensex were both down over 2% at 0500 GMT. The rupee also fell against the dollar and benchmark bond yields were up.\n\nThe markets had soared on Monday after exit polls on June 1 projected Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would register a big victory, with its National Democratic Alliance (NDA) seen getting a two-thirds majority and more. At 0430 GMT, TV channels showed the NDA was ahead in nearly 300 of the 543 elective seats in parliament, a simple majority, in early counting. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was leading in over 200 seats, higher than expected.\n\nOnly about 10%-15% of the total votes had been counted at the time, TV channels said. BJP alone accounted for nearly 250 of the seats in which the NDA was leading, compared to the 303 it won in 2019. Trends also showed Modi leading first, then trailing and leading again in his seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi.\n\nThe first votes counted were postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty. This year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots. \"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out. VITRIOLIC CAMPAIGN\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population. Investors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\" Nearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll that began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour. Modi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\". However, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party, which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's BJP to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign. The opposition INDIA alliance denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8160427390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:05:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:05:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/neighbours/875f17c9c080", "title": "Indian PM Modi's alliance leads in majority of seats in early counting trends, TV says", "body": "People watch election results outside a vote counting centre in Mumbai, India, Jun 4, 2024. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP)-led alliance raced to a clear majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament in early vote-counting trends on Tuesday, TV channels showed.\n\nThe channels showed the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA) was ahead in more than 300 seats, with BJP alone ahead in 255. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was ahead in 172 seats, with Congress alone ahead in 71.\n\nBased on the early trends, the Republic TV channel called the vote in favour of Modi, the first to do so.\n\nThe first votes counted are postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty.\n\nThis year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots.\n\n\"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on Jun 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on Apr 19 and was held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50 degrees Celsius (122 degrees Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66 percent of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's BJP to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. {"uri": "8160340267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:39:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:39:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:39:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/india-begins-counting-640-million-votes-after-six-week-election-1633361.html", "title": "India begins counting 640 million votes after six-week election | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "India has started counting more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return prime minister Narendra Modi for a third term.\n\nThe six-week-long election was seen as a referendum on the 73-year-old, who would be the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Mr Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nAccording to official data, nearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote, with an average turnout of around 66% across the seven phases.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centres in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could continue into Tuesday evening before the Election Commission of India declares a final result.\n\nLeads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, his popularity outstripping that of his party and turning a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become unequal under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nMr Modi's critics say the country's democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly used strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media, and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements his party says have reduced poverty.\n\nHis opposition, the India alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics.\n\nThe alliance hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation, and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of more than a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness.\n\nThe alliance has also claimed they have been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Mr Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow the BJP's thumping win in 2019, winning 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], If the 73-year-old wins, it will be only the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit the polls SATURDAY Major television networks predicted a comfortable victory for Modis' Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies on a large scale. opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nIndian television channels have had mixed results in the past when it comes to predicting election results.\n\nNearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population had the right to vote. The participation rate was around 66% on average across the seven phases, according to official data.\n\nThe counting of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where voting took place could extend into the evening before the final result is declared by the Election Commission of India.\n\nBut leads will start to emerge sooner, which will give an idea of where the results could go.\n\nExtreme heat hit India as voters went to the polls, with temperatures exceeding 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country. Chief Election Commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson. We should have finished the elections at least a month earlier, he said. We shouldn't have let this continue in this much heat.\n\nOn Tuesday, BJP workers outside the party office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual soon after the counting began. Meanwhile, supporters at the Congress party headquarters appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIn 10 years in power, Modi has transformed Indian political landscape. His popularity has surpassed that of his party and transformed a parliamentary election into a campaign that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP is increasingly relying on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians taking a back seat even in national elections.\n\nModi was not just the main campaigner, but the only candidate in this election, said public policy expert Yamini Aiyar.\n\nHis supporters see him as a strong, self-made leader who improved India's standing in the world and credit his business-friendly policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest.\n\nBut a decade under his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Critics and opponents of Modis say his Hindu politics first have spawned intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, particularly Muslims, who make up 14% of the population.\n\nThe Indian economy, one of the most dynamic, has become even more unequal under Modi. As stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small part of the Indians benefiting from the economic boom.\n\nModis' critics say the country's democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly resorted to heavy-handed tactics to subdue political opponents, stifle independent media and suppress dissent. The government has rejected these accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs the elections opened in mid-April, an initially confident BJP focused his campaign on Modis' guarantees, highlighting the economic and social achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, India will become a developed nation by 2047, Modi has repeated in rally after rally.\n\nBut the campaign became increasingly bitter as Modi stepped up his polarizing rhetoric targeting the government. Muslim minoritya tactic meant to energize its core of majority Hindu voters.\n\nHis opposition, the Congress party-led INDIA alliance, has attacked Modi for his Hindu nationalist policies. {"uri": "8160430974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "05:07:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T05:07:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T05:07:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2960585-modis-alliance-leads-early-vote-count-amid-market-jitters", "title": "Modi's Alliance Leads Early Vote Count Amid Market Jitters | Politics", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance is leading in early general election vote counts, although with fewer seats than exit polls predicted. Initial trends caused market instability, with stock indexes and the rupee falling. Postal ballots accounted for early results, with further counting expected to last hours.\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance raced to a majority in early vote counting trends in the general election on Tuesday, but the numbers were well short of the landslide predicted in exit polls, TV channels showed.\n\nThe early see-saw trends unnerved markets with stocks falling steeply. The NIFTY 50 and the S&P BSE Sensex were both down 2.1% at 0434 GMT. The rupee also fell against the dollar and benchmark bond yields were up.\n\nThe markets had soared on Monday after exit polls on June 1 projected Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would register a big victory, with its National Democratic Alliance (NDA) seen getting a two-thirds majority and more. At 0430 GMT, TV channels showed the NDA was ahead in nearly 300 of the 543 elective seats in parliament, a simple majority, in early counting. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was leading in over 200 seats, higher than expected.\n\nOnly about 10%-15% of the total votes had been counted at the time, TV channels said. BJP alone accounted for nearly 250 of the seats in which the NDA was leading, compared to the 303 it won in 2019. Trends also showed Modi leading first, then trailing and leading again in his seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi.\n\nThe first votes counted were postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty. This year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots. \"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out. VITRIOLIC CAMPAIGN\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population. Investors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\" The exit polls projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the Lok Sabha, the lower house of parliament, which would help it usher in far-reaching amendments in the constitution.\n\nMarkets cheered the projections, since it promised the continuation of the growth-focused economic policies of the ruling alliance. Nearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll that began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour. Modi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\". However, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party, which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's BJP to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign. The opposition INDIA alliance denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8160189842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "00:45:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T00:45:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T00:45:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/06/03/indias-marathon-election-enters-final-stage-of-vote-counting-with-modi-widely-tipped-for-third-term/", "title": "India's marathon election enters final stage of vote counting with Modi widely tipped for third term - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Krutika Pathi And Sheikh Saaliq, The Associated Press on June 3, 2024.\n\nPolice officers stand guard at a vote counting centre ahead of the counting for Indian parliamentary elections in Mumbai, India, Monday, June 3, 2024. India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. (AP Photo/Rafiq Maqbool)NEW DELHI (AP) - India's marathon election enters its final phase on Tuesday with the counting of more than 640 million votes in the world's largest democratic exercise, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Narendra Modi to a third term after a decade in power. The 6-week-long election was seen as a referendum on Modi. If the 73-year-old wins, it will only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister. Exit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi. Indian television channels have had a mixed record in the past in predicting election results. Nearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote. Turnout averaged 66% across the seven phases, according to official data. The tallying of votes at counting centers in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could stretch into the evening before a final result is declared by the Election Commission of India. But leads will emerge earlier and indicate where the results may be headed. In his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape. His popularity has outstripped that of his party's, and has turned a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign. The result is that the BJP relies more and more on Modi's enduring brand to stay in power, with local politicians receding into the background even in state elections. \"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\"\u009d said Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar. His supporters see him as a self-made, strong leader who has improved India's standing in the world, and credit his pro-business policies with making the economy the world's fifth-largest. But a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Modi's critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population. India's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become more unequal under Modi. While stock markets reach record-highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom. The country's democracy, Modi's critics say, is faltering under his government, which has increasingly wielded strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and say democracy is flourishing. As polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees,\"\u009d highlighting the economic and welfare achievements that his party says have reduced poverty. With him at the helm, \"India will become a developed nation by 2047,\"\u009d Modi repeated in rally after rally. But the campaign turned increasingly shrill, as Modi ramped up polarizing rhetoric that targeted the Muslim minority, a tactic seen to energize his core Hindu majority voters. His opposition, the INDIA alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics. It hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation and inequality. But the broad alliance of over a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness. Meanwhile, the alliance has also claimed they've been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this. Another victory would cement Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow a thumping win in 2019, when the BJP won 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": Modi will need support from other coalition parties for his third five-year term in office. This result is a setback for the 73-year-old, who had hoped for a landslide victory. However, many of the Hindu nationalist policies he implemented over the past decade remain intact.\n\nModi vowed to fulfill his election promises, including advancing India's economy from the world's fifth to the third largest, boosting defense production, creating jobs for youth, raising exports, and supporting farmers. \"This country will see a new chapter of big decisions. This is Modi's guarantee,\" he said.\n\nThe opposition also claimed a sort of victory, with the Congress party calling the election a \"moral and political loss\" for Modi. \"This is the public's victory and a win for democracy,\" said Congress party President Mallikarjun Kharge.\n\nDuring his 10 years in power, Modi has transformed India's political landscape by bringing Hindu nationalism into the mainstream, leaving the country deeply divided. His supporters view him as a strong, self-made leader who has improved India's global standing. Critics argue that his Hindu-first politics have fostered intolerance, and while the economy has grown, it has also become more unequal.\n\nThe counting of over 640 million votes cast over six weeks was expected to continue into the night. After 12 hours of counting, partial tallies from India's Election Commission showed Modi's BJP ahead in 114 constituencies and winning 126 out of 543 parliamentary seats. The Congress party led in 45 constituencies and won 54 seats.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority. In 2019, the BJP won 303 seats and 282 in 2014. The BJP-led National Democratic Alliance led in 147 constituencies and won 139, while the Congress-led INDIA alliance led in 131 constituencies and won 99. {"uri": "8160358311", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "04:01:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T04:01:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T04:00:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2960454-modis-bjp-poised-for-historic-third-term-amid-market-fluctuations", "title": "Modi's BJP Poised for Historic Third Term Amid Market Fluctuations | Politics", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's BJP-led alliance appears to be heading for a clear majority in early vote counts, securing over 300 seats. Investors are optimistic about sustained economic growth under another Modi term, despite some market nervousness. The opposition has accused the BJP of divisive tactics, while the BJP denies these allegations.\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP)-led alliance raced to a clear majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament in early vote-counting trends on Tuesday, TV channels showed.\n\nThe channels showed the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA) was ahead in more than 300 seats, with BJP alone ahead in 255. The opposition INDIA alliance led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party was ahead in 172 seats, with Congress alone ahead in 71. Based on the early trends, the Republic TV channel called the vote in favour of Modi, the first to do so.\n\nThe first votes counted are postal ballots, which are paper ballots, mostly cast by troops serving outside their home constituencies or officials away from home on election duty. This year, postal votes were also offered to voters over 85 years of age and people with disabilities to allow them to vote from home.\n\nCounting is expected to last several hours as the large majority of votes polled in electronic voting machines or EVMs are taken up after the first 30 minutes of counting postal ballots. \"These are very early trends, we are going to see better results as the day progresses,\" Congress spokesperson Pawan Khera said.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out. However, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear. \"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nMARKETS CHEER India stocks fell at the open after Monday's sharp surge as traders said there was some nervousness on the margin of victory.\n\nThe NIFTY 50 was down 2.2% at 0345 GMT and the S&P BSE Sensex was down 1.8%. TV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019. The projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts. More than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms. He began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive. They said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
