{"uri": "2024-06-378661663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:30:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:30:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:42:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/modi-poised-lose-india-majority-115411400.html", "title": "Modi Vows to Stay in Power Even as Party Loses India Majority", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- arendra Modi vowed to continue as India's prime minister even after his party lost its majority in parliament, forcing him to rely on allies to form a government for the first time since he stormed to power a decade ago.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 240 seats, short of the 272 needed for a majority, while his National Democratic Alliance had 293 seats -- enough to form a government if it sticks together. The opposition bloc, known as the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, was on course to win 229 seats, the results showed.\n\nModi claimed victory for his coalition in a post on X, calling it a \"historical feat.\"\n\n\"I assure the countrymen that to fulfill their aspirations, we will move forward with new energy, new enthusiasm and new resolve,\" Modi said. He was set to address the nation later on Tuesday.\n\nIndia's stocks had their worst day in more than four years, as it became clear the election outcome would be much closer than expected. Markets had hit a record high on Monday after exit polls released over the weekend showed Modi would coast to an easy victory in the marathon, six-week election. Before voting kicked off on April 19, the prime minister had boldly predicted that his alliance would win a whopping 400 seats.\n\n\"This is not an election -- it is a kind of political earthquake,\" said Niranjan Sahoo, senior fellow with the New Delhi-based Observer Research Foundation who has written several books on Indian politics. \"Even if Modi becomes the prime minister, his position will be diminished to a great extent. He will not be the same Modi.\"\n\nIndia Election Results 2024 -- Follow Live Results\n\nModi now needs to secure the support of two key members of his broader National Democratic Alliance who control some 30 seats -- enough to flip the balance of power in parliament. Leaders of those two parties have a history of switching sides, and only joined up with Modi a few months ago, making it unclear whether they will stick with him or back the opposition bloc. A spokesperson of the allies, the Telugu Desam Party in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, affirmed support for Modi's coalition.\n\nMore than 20 opposition parties, spearheaded by Rahul Gandhi, formed a united front in a bid to stop Modi's once-dominant electoral machine. A mixture of regional and caste-based groups, the alliance focused on appealing to voters who felt left out of India's growth story, which has been marked by growing inequality, pervasive joblessness and rising living costs.\n\nAfter the results became clear, Gandhi said the election showed that voters don't want Modi to run the country. The opposition alliance would meet on Wednesday to discuss next steps, he added.\n\n\"We do not like the way they have run this country for the last 10 years,\" Gandhi told reporters on Tuesday. \"That is a huge message to Mr. Narendra Modi.\"\n\nThe result is a stunning disappointment for the 73-year-old leader, who has been the main face of the BJP's election campaign and built the party primarily around himself. Besides raising questions about Modi's own future as prime minister, a weak coalition government will likely make it difficult for him to push through tough economic reforms or further his Hindu nationalist agenda assuming he returns to power.\n\nThe lackluster performance marks the first major setback at national polls for Modi. He had looked unbeatable heading into the election, backed by one of the world's fastest-growing economies and the fulfillment of key promises appealing to India's Hindu majority, including the building of a temple on the site where a 500-year-old mosque had been torn down.\n\nSigns of trouble for Modi emerged after the first of seven rounds of voting. A dip in turnout triggered a broad get-out-the-vote effort that saw Modi adopt a more strident tone, firing up his Hindu nationalist base with divisive anti-Muslim rhetoric and attacks on the opposition's welfare policies.\n\nModi had appealed to India's 1.4 billion people with a combination of business-friendly policies, welfare measures for the poor and Hindu nationalist policies. He had pledged more of the same in his third term, vowing measures to create jobs while also replacing India's religion-based marriage and inheritance laws with a uniform civil code -- a measure that Muslims, Christians and other minorities oppose because it would prevent them from adhering to some faith-based laws.\n\nThose more contentious proposals may now be off the table. The results also call into question whether Modi would have the political capital to implement contentious changes to land and labor laws, as well as a slew of other reform measures needed to achieve his goal of turning India into a developed nation by mid-century.\n\nEven with a reduced mandate or a change in government, India's growth trajectory should largely remain positive. Business leaders from Elon Musk to Jamie Dimon have hailed India's potential as an alternative to China, with some economists projecting that the nation's $3.5 trillion economy can become the largest contributor to global growth within the next five years.\n\n\"As far as economic policy is concerned, fiscal backsliding I think is a risk,\" said Shumita Sharma Deveshwar, senior director of India Research at Global Data.TS Lombard. \"Apart from that I actually don't see much of a change in terms of reform policies. Even with a strong majority, Modi was unable to implement much of the so-called big bang reforms.\"\n\n--With assistance from Debjit Chakraborty, Akriti Sharma, Shruti Srivastava, Menaka Doshi, Rakesh {"uri": "8160042833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:43:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:43:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:42:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-04/india-modi-eyes-historic-win-in-worlds-biggest-election/103930966", "title": "India's Modi eyes historic win in world's biggest election", "body": "What's next? The 642 million votes will be counted on Tuesday, with TV exit polls projecting Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party-led alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the lower house of parliament.\n\nIndia's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equalling third consecutive term in office on Tuesday when the 642 million votes cast in the world's largest election are counted.\n\nExit polls have projected a big win for Modi and if they are confirmed -- they have often got the outcome wrong in India -- Modi's Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver for India further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while rivals and critics fear a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution.\n\nNearly 1 billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and concluded on June 1, held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50 degrees Celsius in some parts.\n\nYet more than 66 per cent of registered voters turned out, just 1 percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, belying fears that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims -- a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he is stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended, projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped, as investors were buoyed by expectations of sustained economic growth.\n\nExit polls, which are conducted by polling agencies, have a patchy record in India, with analysts saying it is a challenge to get them right in the large and diverse country.\n\nOpposition parties dismissed them saying they were unscientific and did not reflect reality.\n\n\"We are very hopeful that our results are completely opposite to what the exit poll is saying,\" former Congress party president and Rahul Gandhi's mother, Sonia, said on Monday.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": {"uri": "8160335483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:34:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:34:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:33:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.ayradvertiser.com/news/national/24363710.india-begins-counting-640-million-votes-six-week-election/", "title": "India begins counting 640 million votes after six-week election", "body": "The six-week-long election was seen as a referendum on the 73-year-old, who would be the second Indian leader to retain power for a third term after Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister.\n\nExit polls on Saturday by major television channels projected a comfortable win for Mr Modi's Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and its allies over a broad opposition alliance led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nAccording to official data, nearly 970 million people, more than 10% of the world's population, were eligible to vote, with an average turnout of around 66% across the seven phases.\n\nThe tallying of votes at counting centres in each of the 543 constituencies where polls were held could continue into Tuesday evening before the Election Commission of India declares a final result.\n\nLeads will start to emerge earlier, which will give an idea of where the results may be headed.\n\nIn his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, his popularity outstripping that of his party and turning a parliamentary election into one that increasingly resembles a presidential-style campaign.\n\nBut a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided. Critics and opponents say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims, who comprise 14% of the population.\n\nIndia's economy, one of the fastest-growing, has become unequal under Mr Modi. While stock markets reach record highs and millionaires multiply, youth unemployment has soared, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom.\n\nMr Modi's critics say the country's democracy is faltering under his government, which has increasingly used strong-arm tactics to subdue political opponents, squeeze independent media, and quash dissent. The government has rejected such accusations and says democracy is flourishing.\n\nAs polls opened in mid-April, a confident BJP initially focused its campaign on \"Modi's guarantees\", highlighting the economic and welfare achievements his party says have reduced poverty.\n\nHis opposition, the India alliance led by the Congress party, has attacked Mr Modi over his Hindu nationalist politics.\n\nThe alliance hopes to benefit from the simmering economic discontent, and its campaign has rallied around issues of joblessness, inflation, and inequality.\n\nBut the broad alliance of more than a dozen political parties has been beset by ideological differences and defections, raising questions over their effectiveness.\n\nThe alliance has also claimed they have been unfairly targeted, pointing to a spree of raids, arrests and corruption investigations against their leaders by federal agencies they say are politically motivated. The government has denied this.\n\nAnother victory would cement Mr Modi as one of the country's most popular and important leaders. It would follow the BJP's thumping win in 2019, winning 303 out of 543 parliamentary seats.", "source": {"uri": "ayradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ayr Advertiser"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-378629532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:41:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/the-latest-india-counts-votes-from-a-mega-election-as-modi-claims-victory-for-his/article_bc7c48ef-e9e9-51a5-aaa5-763238975e3c.html", "title": "The Latest | India counts votes from a mega-election as Modi claims victory for his alliance", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday as early results from the staggered, six-week election showed fewer seats for the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party than expected and it appeared unlikely to secure a majority on its own.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" Modi told a crowd at his party's headquarters. He said his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\nBJP is part of the National Democratic Alliance, which so far had won 67 seats, 62 of them going to BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which so far had won 31 seats, 27 of them for Congress.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in the 543-seat Parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million people -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to vote and turnout averaged 66%, according to official data. The tallying at counting centers in 543 constituencies could stretch well into the evening before final results are announced, though substantial leads are likely to emerge earlier.\n\nIndia's vote is the latest in an unusually busy stretch of elections around the world that are challenging the status quo.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- What to know as votes are being counted.\n\n-- The world's largest election, in photos.\n\n-- Voting ended Saturday in the election that's a referendum on Modi's decade in power.\n\n-- A scorching heat wave killed 14 in India before the final phase of voting.\n\n-- Modi touts India's roaring economy, but many feel left behind.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nMODI SAYS INDIA WILL SEE 'A NEW CHAPTER OF BIG DECISIONS'\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi says India will will see a \"new chapter of big decisions\" in his third term in office.\n\nAfter claiming victory for his coalition alliance despite a lacklustre performance from his own party, Modi told a crowd at party headquarters he would not shirk from pushing forward with his agenda.\n\nHe said he would advance India's defense production, jobs for youth, raise exports and help farmers, among other things.\n\n\"This country will see a new chapter of big decisions. This is Modi's guarantee,\" he said, speaking in the third person.\n\nBJP FACING MAJOR UPSET IN UTTAR PRADESH\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party is facing a major upset in India's most populous state of Uttar Pradesh at the hands of a powerful regional group, Samajwadi Party, or Socialist Group.\n\nThe Samajwadi Party, led my Akhilesh Yadav, already had won 10 seats and was leading in another 28 seats. Its ally, the Congress party, won four seats and was leading in another two.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party had won 12 seats and was leading in 20 seats. Exit polls had predicted a landslide victory for BJP in all 80 seats.\n\nModi was among the winners in the state from the Varanasi constituency. Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party won in his family bastion of Rae Bareli.\n\nIn January, Modi inaugurated a massive temple for Lord Ram in Varanasi.\n\nRajendra Chaudhry, spokesperson for the Samajwadi Party, said: \"In this election, it seems Lord Ram has deserted the BJP.\"\n\nThe Samajwadi Party was founded in 1992 by Mulayam Singh Yadav, who served as its top elected official for several years. His son, Akhilesh Yadav, took over the party leadership after his death.\n\nMODI SAYS HIS COALITION ON THE PATH TO WIN A THIRD TERM\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term in government after India's marathon election.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in NDA, for a third consecutive time! This is a historical feat in India's history,\" Modi said in a post on X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance headed by his party. He said he will continue to work and fulfil the aspirations of the people.\n\nAs Modi posted his comment, his coalition had won 128 seats and led in 157 races, according to the Election Commission. A total of 272 seats are needed to form a majority government.\n\nINDIA'S OPPOSITION SAYS STRONG SHOWING 'A WIN FOR DEMOCRACY'\n\nIndia's opposition Congress party has called its alliance's strong showing in the polls a \"win for democracy\" and a \"moral and political loss\" for Prime Minister Narendra Modi.\n\nCongress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told a news conference in New Delhi that because no party had a clear majority, the mandate was against Modi.\n\n\"Our fight has not ended yet. We will continue to fight for the country's development, for the constitution, for the benefit of the people,\" Kharge said.\n\nModi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected.\n\nRahul Gandhi, the face of the Congress party's campaign, said the results showed India does not want Modi.\n\n\"People's clear message to PM Modi and Home Minister Amit shah is that we don't want you to run the nation,\" Gandhi said. \"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India.\"\n\nMODI WINS SEAT IN VARANASI\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi has won a seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi, where he ran in 2014 and 2019, India's Election Commission reported.\n\nModi won by more than 152,000 votes and secured 54% of total votes. He ran against the Congress party's Ajai Rai, who got 40%.\n\nVaranasi is located on the banks of the revered Ganges River and is part of Uttar Pradesh state, India's most populous, with around 200 million people.\n\nBJP LOSES SEAT IN AYODHYA, WHERE MODI OPENED A GRAND TEMPLE IN JANUARY\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's party has lost a seat in the Ayodhya constituency, a deeply symbolic loss after he opened a grand but controversial Hindu temple there in January.\n\nThe Bharatiya Janata Party candidate, Lallu Singh, lost to a rival from the regional Samajwadi Party, Singh's poll agent Kamlesh Srivastava told The Associated Press.\n\nModi and his party had campaigned heavily at the temple dedicated to Lord Ram, built on the historic ruins of a mosque that was destroyed by Hindu mobs in 1992.\n\nExperts said the January opening, where Modi performed rituals inside the temple, marked the unofficial start of his campaign as they hoped it would resonate with his Hindu majority voters. Modi's government had turned it into a national event by organizing live screenings across the country and closing offices for half a day.\n\nThe BJP had held a seat in Ayodhya since 2014.\n\nMODI'S PARTY WINS 19, CONGRESS PARTY 4 SEATS IN CONFIRMED RACES\n\nWhile the vote counting is still continuing, results have been called for 28 parliamentary seats out of 542 so far.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party has won 19 seats, according to India's Election Commission, while the main opposition Congress party secured four seats. The rest went to different regional parties.\n\nVote tallying is expected to take all day Tuesday, but the count so far shows Modi's party leading in 224 seats with the Congress ahead in 98.\n\nEARLY TALLIES SHOW MODI'S BJP LEADING IN 25 OF 26 SEATS IN HIS HOME STATE\n\nEarly leads by India's election commission projected Modi's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 25 of 26 seats in the prime minister's home state of Gujarat. But party leaders said they were not celebrating victory due to a recent blaze at an amusement park in the state that killed 27 people, including children.\n\nA massive fire broke out in May at an amusement park in the state's Rajkot city.\n\n\"We had decided that there will be no celebratory victory or beating of drums. So we are not celebrating,\" said C. R. Patil, a senior leader from Modi's party.\n\nMODI MAY NEED A COALITION TO KEEP HIS JOB\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling Hindu nationalist party appeared to be falling short of a majority in the early vote count Tuesday. If these trends hold, it would be a stunning setback to the populist prime minister who has never relied on coalition partners to govern.\n\nBharatiya Janata Party is still expected to form the new government and return Modi as the prime minister for a rare third consecutive term as his National Democratic Alliance was leading in about 290 seats. A majority requires 272 seats. BJP alone was leading in 242 seats.\n\nStill, that's not the strong finish Modi was aiming for after his party won landslide victories in the 2014 and 2019 elections.\n\nIf BJP doesn't win a majority on its own, it could \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" Vaishnav said.\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi's BJP has governed in a coalition government but has always had a majority on its own.\n\nINDIA'S MAIN STOCK INDICES CLOSE SHARPLY DOWN AS EARLY VOTE TALLIES SHOW A CLOSER RACE THAN EXPECTED\n\nAs the early vote count showed Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party facing a tighter than expected race, India's two main benchmark stock indices closed down sharply.\n\nThe NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex had hit new highs at the close of day Monday but dropped sharply Tuesday as the early vote figures started to come in.\n\nThey recovered slightly to each close down more than 5%.\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople.\n\nEven if Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party does not secure a parliamentary majority on its own, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed his coalition, which includes smaller parties, still could.\n\nJAILED POLITICIAN WINS NORTHERN BARAMULLA CONSTITUENCY AFTER OPPONENT CONCEDES\n\nA politician from disputed Kashmir who has been in New Delhi's Tihar Jail since 2019 in a terror funding case has won after his rival conceded defeat.\n\nSheikh Abdul Rashid from northern Baramulla constituency won as an independent candidate, beating former chief minister of the region Omar Abdullah.\n\n\"I think it's time to accept the inevitable,\" Abdullah wrote on X. \"I don't believe his victory will hasten his release from prison nor will the people of North Kashmir get the representation they have a right to but the voters have spoken and in a democracy that's all that matters.\"\n\nRashid's campaign was run by his two sons, hoping a win for him would lead to his release from prison. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir, which is divided between the neighbors but claimed by both in its entirety. Modi's government revoked Indian-controlled Kashmir's semi-autonomous status during a 2019 security clampdown.\n\nRebel groups in the region have been fighting against Indian rule since 1989. Tens of thousands of people have been killed in the armed uprising and subsequent Indian military crackdown. The rebels want Kashmir to be united under Pakistani rule or become an independent country.\n\nOPPOSITION SHOWS SURPRISING EARLY LEADS IN UTTAR PRADESH, INDIA'S MOST POPULOUS STATE\n\nIndia's most populous state is showing surprising early leads for the opposition, despite being previously controlled by Modi's Hindu nationalist party.\n\nEarly tallies reported by the Election Commission showed the opposition Congress party and its ally, the Samajwadi Party, were leading on more than half the seats in the crucial northern Uttar Pradesh state ruled by a Hindu monk who is considered a future prime minister candidate by Modi supporters.\n\nUttar Pradesh sends the most lawmakers of any state -- 80 -- to Parliament. It has long been considered the biggest prize in Indian elections. It's also home to Ayodhya, where a Hindu temple was built on the site of a razed mosque.\n\nThe Samajwadi Party was leading in 35 seats, with Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party ahead in 34 seats. The Congress party was leading in seven seats.\n\nIn the 2019 election, BJP won 62 seats in the state.\n\nMODI'S BJP IS AHEAD IN EARLY TALLIES, BUT WITH A STRONGER OPPOSITION SHOWING THAN EXPECTED\n\nIndia's Election Commission says early counting of votes shows incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead, but with a stronger than expected showing by the main opposition.\n\nSome six hours into counting, Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two -- including one uncontested -- of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nThe main opposition Congress party was leading in 99 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting is expected to go on through the day. A total of some 642 million votes are being counted in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties were leading in 283 constituencies according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which was leading in 232 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in parliament.\n\nINDIAN MARKETS ARE DOWN SHARPLY AS EARLY TALLIES SHOW A STRONGER CHALLENGE FROM THE OPPOSITION THAN EXPECTED\n\nIndian markets, which closed at an all-time high Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, after early leads showed fewer seats for Modi's governing BJP than had been expected.\n\nModi's party still showed a comfortable lead, according to early figures reported by India's election commission. but was facing a stronger challenge from the opposition than exit polls had projected.\n\nIndia's benchmark stock indices, the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex, were both down by more than 8% before recovering slightly. This followed a dip of more than 3% when markets opened.\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople.\n\nWORKERS TAKE HEAT PRECAUTIONS AS VOTES ARE COUNTED IN TEMPERATURES EXPECTED TOO REACH 106F\n\nTemperatures in the Indian capital were down Tuesday from highs in the past week of 45 degrees Celsius (113 degrees Fahrenheit), but election officials and political parties were nonetheless taking precautions as votes were being counted.\n\nWorkers carried cases of water into one air-conditioned counting station in New Delhi early in the morning in preparation, while tents outside for security personnel and others were outfitted with industrial evaporative coolers.\n\nTemperatures in the morning hovered around 37 C (99 F) in New Delhi and were expected to rise to 41 C (106 F) by the end of the day.\n\nAt the headquarters of the opposition Congress party, a tent was set up outside, equipped with evaporative coolers, for waiting media.\n\nWOMEN ARE A KEY VOTING BLOC IN INDIA'S 2024 ELECTION\n\nIndian women are a key voting bloc with more of them voting in recent elections than ever before. Most poll experts expect women voters to play a decisive role in determining the 2024 election results.\n\nPolitical parties have been wooing them with monthly cash handouts, subsidized cooking gas cylinders and low-interest loans. Many such programs have particularly helped Modi's Bharatiya Janata party widen its support among them, especially in rural areas. The opposition alliance also tried to gain women's votes by unveiling programs that promised financial aid of $1,200 per year to poor women, and promised to reserve 50% of government jobs for women if voted into power.\n\nWomen make up nearly 49% of India's total electorate. Turnout has grown in each recent major election -- of women who were eligible to vote, 53% voted in 2004; 56% in 2009; 65.5% in 2014; and 67% in 2019. Data for 2024 was not yet available but was estimated to resemble 2019's female voter turnout.\n\nCOUNTING STARTS WITH POSTAL BALLOTS THEN MOVES TO ELECTRONIC ONES\n\nThe counting of some 642 million votes cast in India's election is being done at various locations around the country by government employees. Chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said they were starting with postal ballots and then move on to combining the votes from India's electronic voting machines.\n\nThe process is expected to be completed by the end of the day Tuesday.\n\nIndia has close to 970 million eligible voters, and votes were cast at more than a million polling stations staggered over the last six weeks.\n\nThat brought the final phase into India's hottest season, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country, and Kumar said the election officials learned a valuable lesson.\n\n\"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said ahead of the start of the counting. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\nFollow Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equalling third consecutive term in office as the counting of 642 million votes in the world's largest election begins.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on Saturday projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50C in some parts.\n\nMore than 66 per cent of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters.", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/india-election-early-vote-counts-suggest-narendra-modis-party-may-struggle-to-secure-majority-13147630", "title": "India election: Early vote counts suggest Narendra Modi's party may struggle to secure majority", "body": "India's popular but controversial leader, who first swept to power in 2014, is hoping to secure a third consecutive term as prime minister.\n\nEarly counting of votes in India's election suggests the party of Narendra Modi may get fewer seats than expected.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in the country's parliament - but his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is so far ahead only in 242 seats.\n\nHowever, if it is unable to achieve an outright majority, the BJP is expected to form a coalition government - ensuring Mr Modi securing a third consecutive term as prime minister.\n\nThe BJP is part of a broader National Democratic Alliance of parties - which are ahead in a total of 283 constituencies.\n\nIf Mr Modi does lead a coalition government, the popular but controversial 73-year-old leader, who first swept to power in 2014, would become only the second prime minister - after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru - to win three consecutive terms.\n\nThe counting of 642 million votes in the world's largest election began early today.\n\nThe Hindu nationalist BJP and its allies have faced a broad opposition alliance in the poll led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi.\n\nAround 970 million people - more than 10% of the world's population - were eligible to vote after polls opened in mid-April, with an average turnout of around 66% across the seven phases, according to official figures.\n\nDuring his 10 years in power, Mr Modi has transformed India's political landscape, his popularity outstripping that of his party.\n\nHowever, a decade of his leadership has also left the country deeply divided - religiously and economically.\n\nHis opponents and critics say his Hindu-first politics have bred intolerance, hate speech and brazen attacks against the country's minorities - raising concerns over the treatment of Muslims, Christians and other religious groups.\n\nIndia's economy is among the fastest-growing in the world and has helped the country emerge as a global power and a counterweight to China.\n\nBut it has become unequal, with only a small portion of Indians benefitting from the economic boom and youth unemployment soaring.\n\nThe country's democratic values under Mr Modi's leadership have also come under scrutiny.\n\nUnder Mr Modi, the media - once viewed as vibrant and largely independent - has become more pliant and critical voices muzzled.\n\nMany watchdogs have now categorised India as a \"hybrid regime\" that is neither a full democracy nor a full autocracy.\n\nMr Modi's government has repeatedly denied and dismissed accusations of discrimination, saying its policies aim for the {"uri": "2024-06-377064753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "10:50:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T10:50:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T10:15:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/ap-photos-the-worlds-largest-elections-come-to-a-close-in-india/article_5ecf37ed-28a9-5d41-ab87-d5e4e31b25c0.html", "title": "AP Photos: The world's largest elections come to a close in India", "body": "New Delhi (AP) -- The 6-week-long election in India closed on Saturday. The world's largest election could also be one of its most consequential. Voters are choosing 543 members for the lower house of Parliament for a five-year term.\n\nIndia has close to 970 million voters among its more than 1.4 billion people, and its general election pits Prime Minister Narendra Modi, an avowed Hindu nationalist, against a broad alliance of opposition parties that are struggling to play catch up.\n\nThe vote counting will start Tuesday and will be updated throughout the day. The election results will likely be known the same day.\n\nVotes were cast at more than a million polling stations. Each of the seven voting phases lasted a single day with several constituencies across multiple states voting that day. The staggered polling allowed the government to transport election officials and voting machines and deploy tens of thousands of troops to prevent violence. Candidates crisscrossed the country, poll workers hiked to remote villages, and voters lined up for hours in sweltering heat.\n\nMillions of Indians waited anxiously as the election authority prepared to count on Tuesday 642 million votes polled in the national election during a grueling six-week period.\n\nSupporters of Prime Minister Narendra Modi' and his Hindu nationalist party were already in a celebratory mood with exit polls predicting a massive win and a third term for Modi as India's prime minister.\n\nMost exit polls project Modi is set to extend his decade in power with a third consecutive term, especially after he opened a Hindu temple in northern Ayodhya city in January, which fulfilled his party's long-held Hindu nationalist pledge. During the polls Modi escalated polarizing rhetoric in incendiary speeches that targeted the country's Muslim minority.\n\nIndia's Chief Election Commissioner, Rajiv Kumar said 642 million voters exercising their right in India was a world record.\n\n''It's a miracle,' Kumar said.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8160288129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "02:46:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T02:46:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T02:44:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13491567/UPDATE-1-Indias-Modi-eyes-biggest-win-votes-counted-giant-election.html", "title": "UPDATE 1-India's Modi eyes biggest win yet as votes are counted in...", "body": "By YP Rajesh and Tanvi Mehta\n\nNEW DELHI, June 4 (Reuters) - India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equalling third consecutive term in office as the counting of 642 million votes in the world's largest election began on Tuesday.\n\nTV exit polls broadcast after voting ended on June 1 projected a big win for Modi, but exit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nIndia stock futures edged higher and the rupee was steady before the count began at 8:00 a.m. (0230 GMT) on Tuesday. The NIFTY 50 index futures rose 0.21% in early trade, according to NSE International Exchange data, and was looking at another record high open.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favor.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee.\"\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favoring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favored Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters. {"uri": "8160354249", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "03:57:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T03:57:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T03:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://theprint.in/india/indias-modi-eyes-biggest-win-yet-as-votes-are-counted-in-giant-election/2114947/", "title": "India's Modi eyes biggest win yet as votes are counted in giant election", "body": "However, if Modi's victory is confirmed, his Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered the prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear.\n\n\"The next government's main task will be to set India on the path of getting rich before it ages,\" the Times of India newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, referring to the young, working age population in the world's most populous nation. \"The clock's ticking.\"\n\nIndia stock futures edged higher and the rupee was steady before the count began at 8:00 a.m. (0230 GMT) on Tuesday. The NIFTY 50 index futures rose 0.21% in early trade, according to NSE International Exchange data, and was looking at another record high open.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament.\n\nSeveral major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped.\n\nNearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nMore than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, squashing pre-poll concerns that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour.\n\nModi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\".\n\nHowever, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he was stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign.\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this.\n\nThe opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters.\n\n(Reporting by YP Rajesh and Tanvi Mehta; Editing by Toby Chopra and Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378206424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:52:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:52:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/modi-poised-win-third-term-090001281.html", "title": "Modi poised to win third term but may fall short of landslide victory in Indian election", "body": "India's prime minister, Narendra Modi, looks poised to win a third term in power - but early election results indicate he has not achieved the landslide victory many had predicted.\n\nBy early Tuesday afternoon, with half of the 640m votes counted, initial results showed that Modi's Bharatiya Janata party (BJP) and its political allies had won 290 seats, enough to form a majority government to rule for the next five years.\n\nHowever, it was a decline from their 2019 victory. The BJP was on course to lose almost 70 constituencies, winning just 240 seats, meaning it will have to rely on its alliance partners to achieve the 272 majority. The outcome so far is a distinct departure from the two-thirds majority that many exit polls had predicted at the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, the opposition alliance, which goes by the acronym INDIA, appeared to far outperform expectations, collectively winning 234 seats, according to the early count. The alliance, formed of more than 20 national and regional opposition parties, had come together for the first time in this election with the aim of defeating Modi, who has been in power since 2014.\n\nThe early results were a particular triumph for the country's main opposition party and the BJP's main rival, Indian National Congress, which had dramatically lost the previous two elections to Modi and was facing questions about its future as a party. However, it appeared the Congress party had doubled its seats in this election.\n\nShould the results remain consistent as counting continues, it could have significant implications for India's political landscape after the polls. Since he was elected a decade ago, Modi and his Hindu nationalist BJP party have enjoyed a powerful majority, while the opposition - particularly the Congress party - have been seen as weak and unable to stand up to the might of the BJP.\n\nRelated: 'Modi builds highways but where are our jobs?': rising inequality looms over India's election\n\nBut the INDIA coalition proved more resilient than many analysts had expected and was boosted by strong performances by regional parties such as the Samajwadi party in Uttar Pradesh, the Trinamool Congress in West Bengal and Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam party in Tamil Nadu.\n\nOne of the biggest shocks of the early results was the apparent losses faced by the BJP in Uttar Pradesh, the country's most populous and politically important state, which has 80 seats and is seen as a bellwether for the rest of the country. Early counts showed that the INDIA alliance was ahead of the BJP's alliance, with parties gaining more than 30 seats.\n\nIn the aftermath of the election, it appears likely that Modi will have to face a more powerful and more animated opposition than at any point over the past decade. The results also indicate that the \"Modi wave\" has been dented by problems such as high unemployment and inflation.\n\nThe BJP is still likely to have an outright majority, meaning it can freely move forward with Modi's flagship Hindu nationalist agenda and economic changes in his third term. However, without the two-thirds parliamentary majority the party had aimed for, it will not be able to amend India's secular constitution, as many had feared.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8161311047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:42:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:42:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:41:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/world/2024/06/04/modi-set-to-lose-india-majority-in-worlds-largest-democratic-election/", "title": "Modi set to lose India majority in world's largest democratic election", "body": "Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 240 seats, short of the 272 needed to form a government.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party is poised to lose its majority in parliament, forcing him to rely on allies to form a government. It's a stunning blow to a leader who has dominated Indian politics since he first took power a decade ago.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 240 seats, short of the 272 needed to form a government and well behind the 303 it won in the 2019 election. The opposition bloc, known as the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, was on course to win 229 seats, the results showed.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIndia's NSE Nifty 50 Index tumbled 5.9%, its worst day in more than four years, as it became clear the election outcome would be much closer than expected. Stocks had hit a record high on Monday after exit polls released over the weekend showed Modi would coast to an easy victory in the marathon, six-week election. Before voting kicked off on April 19, he had boldly predicted that his alliance would win a whopping 400 seats.\n\nAdvertisementBreaking News\n\nGet the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\n\"This is not an election - it is a kind of political earthquake,\" said Niranjan Sahoo, senior fellow with the New Delhi-based Observer Research Foundation who has written several books on Indian politics. \"Even if Modi becomes the prime minister, his position will be diminished to a great extent. He will not be the same Modi.\"\n\nModi now needs to secure the support of two key members of his broader National Democratic Alliance who control some 30 seats - enough to flip the balance of power in parliament. Leaders of those two parties have a history of switching sides, and only joined up with Modi a few months ago, making it unclear whether they will stick with him or back the opposition bloc.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMore than 20 opposition parties, spearheaded by Rahul Gandhi, formed a united front in a bid to stop Modi's once-dominant electoral machine. A mixture of regional and caste-based groups, the alliance focused on appealing to voters who felt left out of India's growth story, which has been marked by growing inequality, pervasive joblessness and rising living costs.\n\nAfter the results became clear, Gandhi said the election showed that voters don't want Modi to run the country. The opposition alliance would meet on Wednesday to discuss next steps, he added.\n\n\"We do not like the way they have run this country for the last 10 years,\" Gandhi told reporters on Tuesday. \"That is a huge message to Mr. Narendra Modi.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe result is a disappointment for the 73-year-old leader, who has been the main face of the BJP's election campaign and built the party primarily around himself. Besides raising questions about Modi's own future as prime minister, a weak coalition government will likely make it difficult for him to push through tough economic reforms or further his Hindu nationalist agenda assuming he returns to power.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe lackluster performance marks the first major setback at national polls for Modi. He had looked unbeatable heading into the election, backed by one of the world's fastest-growing economies and the fulfillment of key promises appealing to India's Hindu majority, including the building of a temple on the site where a 500-year-old mosque had been torn down.\n\nSigns of trouble for Modi emerged after the first of seven rounds of voting. A dip in turnout triggered a broad get-out-the-vote effort that saw Modi adopt a more strident tone, firing up his Hindu nationalist base with divisive anti-Muslim rhetoric and attacks on the opposition's welfare policies.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nModi had appealed to India's 1.4 billion people with a combination of business-friendly policies, welfare measures for the poor and Hindu nationalist policies. He had pledged more of the same in his third term, vowing measures to create jobs while also replacing India's religion-based marriage and inheritance laws with a uniform civil code -- a measure that Muslims, Christians and other minorities oppose because it would prevent them from adhering to some faith-based laws.\n\nThose more contentious proposals may now be off the table. The results also call into question whether Modi would have the political capital to implement contentious changes to land and labor laws, as well as a slew of other reform measures needed to achieve his goal of turning India into a developed nation by mid-century.\n\nEven with a reduced mandate or a change in government, India's growth trajectory should largely remain positive. Business leaders from Elon Musk to Jamie Dimon have hailed India's potential as an alternative to China, with some economists projecting that the nation's $3.5 trillion economy can become the largest contributor to global growth within the next five years.\n\n\"As far as economic policy is concerned, fiscal backsliding I think is a risk,\" said Shumita Sharma Deveshwar, senior director of India Research at Global Data.TS Lombard. \"Apart from that I actually don't see much of a change in terms of reform policies. Even with a strong majority, Modi was unable to implement much of the so-called big bang reforms.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n- By Swati Gupta and Dan Strumpf for Bloomberg with assistance from Debjit Chakraborty, Akriti Sharma, Shruti Srivastava, Menaka Doshi, Rakesh Sharma and Preeti Soni.\n\nRelated StoriesRead MoreWhat to know as votes are counted in India's electionVotes were cast through Saturday at more than a million polling stations in India. Veteran war correspondent Wes Gallagher -- who would later run the entire Associated Press -- directed AP's team from the headquarters in Portsmouth, England, of Supreme Allied Commander Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.Remembering D-Day: Facts, figures, timeline of the battle that changed the course of WWIIWith veterans and world dignitaries gathering in Normandy to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the This election, marked by high voter turnout and a divisive campaign, could bring substantial economic reforms and constitutional changes, despite opposition concerns.\n\nIndia's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to win a record-equalling third consecutive term in office on Tuesday when the 642 million votes cast in the world's largest election are counted. Exit polls have projected a big win for Modi and if they are confirmed - they have often got the outcome wrong in India - Modi's Hindu nationalists will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nInvestors have already cheered\n\nthe prospects of another Modi term, expecting it to deliver for India further years of strong economic growth and pro-business reforms, while a possible two-thirds majority in parliament could allow major changes to the constitution, rivals and critics fear. Nearly one billion people were eligible to vote in the seven-phase, seven-week poll which began on April 19 and concluded on June 1, held in searing summer heat with temperatures touching nearly 50\u00b0 Celsius (122\u00b0 Fahrenheit) in some parts.\n\nYet more than 66% of registered voters turned out, just one percentage point lower than the previous election in 2019, belying fears that voters might shun a contest thought to be a foregone conclusion in Modi's favour. Modi, 73, who first swept to power in 2014 by promising growth and change, is seeking to be only the second prime minister after India's independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru to win three straight terms.\n\nHe began his campaign by showcasing his record in office including economic growth, welfare policies, national pride, Hindu nationalism and his own personal commitment to fulfilling promises which he called \"Modi's Guarantee\". However, he changed tack after low voter turnout in the first phase and accused the opposition, especially the Congress party which leads an alliance of two dozen groups, of favouring India's 200 million Muslims - a shift analysts said made the campaign coarse and divisive.\n\nThey said the pivot may have been aimed at firing up the Hindu nationalist base of Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to draw them to vote. Modi defended himself against criticism that he is stoking divisions between Hindus and Muslims to win votes and said that he was only faulting the opposition campaign. VERY HOPEFUL, SAYS OPPOSITION\n\nThe opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's Congress party, denied it favoured Muslims in the Hindu-majority country and said Modi would destroy the constitution if he returned to power and end affirmative action enjoyed by the so-called backward castes. The BJP rejects this. The opposition alliance also promised more welfare measures and handouts, with surveys saying unemployment, inflation and rural distress were the main concerns of voters.\n\nTV exit polls released on Saturday after voting ended projected the BJP-led National Democratic Alliance could win a two-thirds majority in the 543-member lower house of parliament. Several major polls projected the BJP alone could win more than the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nThe projections pushed Indian shares to lifetime highs on Monday while the rupee gained and bond yields dropped, as investors were buoyed by expectations of sustained economic growth. Exit polls, which are conducted by polling agencies, have a patchy record in India, with analysts saying it is a challenge to get them right in the large and diverse country.\n\nOpposition parties dismissed them saying they were unscientific and did not reflect reality. \"We are very hopeful that our results are completely opposite to what the exit poll is saying,\" former Congress party president and Rahul Gandhi's mother, Sonia, said on Monday.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-378510898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:07:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/world/article288994139.html", "title": "Modi set to lose India majority, needs allies to keep power", "body": "By Swati Gupta and Dan Strumpf, Bloomberg News The Tribune Content Agency\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party is poised to lose its majority in parliament, forcing him to rely on allies to form a government. It's a stunning blow to a leader who has dominated Indian politics since he first took power a decade ago.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 240 seats, short of the 272 needed to form a government and well behind the 303 it won in the 2019 election. The opposition bloc, known as the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, was on course to win 229 seats, the results showed.\n\nIndia's NSE Nifty 50 Index tumbled 5.9%, its worst day in more than four years, as it became clear the election outcome would be much closer than expected. Stocks had hit a record high on Monday after exit polls released over the weekend showed Modi would coast to an easy victory in the marathon, six-week election. Before voting kicked off on April 19, he had boldly predicted that his alliance would win a whopping 400 seats.\n\n\"This is not an election - it is a kind of political earthquake,\" said Niranjan Sahoo, senior fellow with the New Delhi-based Observer Research Foundation who has written several books on Indian politics. \"Even if Modi becomes the prime minister, his position will be diminished to a great extent. He will not be the same Modi.\"\n\nModi now needs to secure the support of two key members of his broader National Democratic Alliance who control some 30 seats - enough to flip the balance of power in parliament. Leaders of those two parties have a history of switching sides, and only joined up with Modi a few months ago, making it unclear whether they will stick with him or back the opposition bloc.\n\nMore than 20 opposition parties, spearheaded by Rahul Gandhi, formed a united front in a bid to stop Modi's once-dominant electoral machine. A mixture of regional and caste-based groups, the alliance focused on appealing to voters who felt left out of India's growth story, which has been marked by growing inequality, pervasive joblessness and rising living costs.\n\nAfter the results became clear, Gandhi said the election showed that voters don't want Modi to run the country. The opposition alliance would meet on Wednesday to discuss next steps, he added.\n\n\"We do not like the way they have run this country for the last 10 years,\" Gandhi told reporters on Tuesday. \"That is a huge message to Mr. Narendra Modi.\"\n\nThe result is a disappointment for the 73-year-old leader, who has been the main face of the BJP's election campaign and built the party primarily around himself. Besides raising questions about Modi's own future as prime minister, a weak coalition government will likely make it difficult for him to push through tough economic reforms or further his Hindu nationalist agenda assuming he returns to power.\n\nThe lackluster performance marks the first major setback at national polls for Modi. He had looked unbeatable heading into the election, backed by one of the world's fastest-growing economies and the fulfillment of key promises appealing to India's Hindu majority, including the building of a temple on the site where a 500-year-old mosque had been torn down.\n\nSigns of trouble for Modi emerged after the first of seven rounds of voting. A dip in turnout triggered a broad get-out-the-vote effort that saw Modi adopt a more strident tone, firing up his Hindu nationalist base with divisive anti-Muslim rhetoric and attacks on the opposition's welfare policies.\n\nModi had appealed to India's 1.4 billion people with a combination of business-friendly policies, welfare measures for the poor and Hindu nationalist policies. He had pledged more of the same in his third term, vowing measures to create jobs while also replacing India's religion-based marriage and inheritance laws with a uniform civil code - a measure that Muslims, Christians and other minorities oppose because it would prevent them from adhering to some faith-based laws.\n\nThose more contentious proposals may now be off the table. The results also call into question whether Modi would have the political capital to implement contentious changes to land and labor laws, as well as a slew of other reform measures needed to achieve his goal of turning India into a developed nation by mid-century.\n\nEven with a reduced mandate or a change in government, India's growth trajectory should largely remain positive. Business leaders from Elon Musk to Jamie Dimon have hailed India's potential as an alternative to China, with some economists projecting that the nation's $3.5 trillion economy can become the largest contributor to global growth within the next five years.\n\n\"As far as economic policy is concerned, fiscal backsliding I think is a risk,\" said Shumita Sharma Deveshwar, senior director of India Research at Global Data.TS Lombard. \"Apart from that I actually don't see much of a change in terms of reform policies. Even with a strong majority, Modi was unable to implement much of the so-called big bang reforms.\"\n\n-With assistance from Debjit Chakraborty, Akriti Sharma, Shruti Srivastava, Menaka Doshi, Rakesh {"uri": "2024-06-378112960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "08:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T08:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T08:24:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-06-04/narendra-modi-india-election-result-2024", "title": "India's Narendra Modi on course to win third term as prime minister", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi looks set to win a third five-year term in office, according to early figures reported by the country's election commission.\n\nHe looked to have a comfortable lead ahead of the opposition but faced a tougher challenge from other parties than had been expected.\n\nMore than 640 million votes were cast over the last six weeks in what was the world's largest ever election.\n\nThe preliminary figures showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) ahead in 240 constituencies out of 542 and winning one uncontested race. The main opposition Congress party was leading in 94 constituencies, around four hours into the count.\n\nThe National Democratic Alliance (NDA) group of parties, led by Modi, was leading in 287 constituencies, while the opposition INDIA alliance, led by the Congress party and its main campaign leader, Rahul Gandhi, was leading in 225.\n\nExit polling from the weekend had projected the NDA to win more than 350 seats.\n\nSome 642 million people voted in the election, with a turnout of around 66% across the seven voting phases, official data showed.\n\nVoting took place over six weeks due to its sheer scale, with different phases of voting taking place across different regions.\n\nAround 15 million polling staff and election monitors, as well as the security services, moved between locations, with voters travelling by whatever means necessary to reach voting centres - whether by car, bus, taxi, motorbike, boat, camel, buffalo or on foot.\n\nExtreme heat struck the country as voters went to the polls, with temperatures soaring above 50.5C in some parts of northern India. At least 10 election workers died because of the scorching heat, officials said.\n\nChief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said officials had learned a valuable lesson and that the election should have been completed \"at least one month before\".\n\n\"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat,\" he said.\n\nWant a quick and expert briefing on the biggest news stories? Listen to our latest podcasts to find out What You Need To Know...\n\nTemperatures were somewhat lower on Tuesday for the counting, but election officials and political parties still took precautions, hauling in large quantities of water and installing coolers for people outside the buildings where votes were being tallied and at party headquarters.\n\nAs counting got underway, BJP workers outside the party's office in New Delhi performed a Hindu ritual. Supporters at the Congress party headquarters also appeared upbeat and chanted slogans praising Gandhi, the party's campaign face.\n\nIf 73-year-old Modi does win, it would only be the second time an Indian leader has retained power for a third term, after Jawaharlal Nehru, who was the country's first prime minister when it declared independence in 1947.\n\nModi has transformed India's political landscape over his decade in power, and his popularity has outstripped that of his party.\n\n\"Modi was not just the prime campaigner, but the sole campaigner of this election,\" Yamini Aiyar, a public policy scholar, said.\n\nBut critics of Modi say that his Hindu-first politics have led to an uptick in intolerance, hate speech and attacks against the country's minorities, especially Muslims.\n\nThe country's finances have also become more divided while Modi has been in power.\n\nStock markets have reached record highs and the country is on track to become the third-largest economy in the world by 2027, but youth unemployment has soared and some say only a small minority of Indians have benefitted from the economic boom.\n\nThe finalised result of the general election {"uri": "8158145595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-02", "time": "17:55:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-02T17:55:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-02T17:52:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2726280/", "title": "Exit polls project victory for Modi as India election concludes - ExBulletin", "body": "Voting has ended in India's mammoth election, with exit polls projecting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party and its allies to win a large majority in Parliament.\n\nVoters voted for 57 parliamentary constituencies on Saturday in the seventh phase of voting which stretched over six weeks in the scorching summer heat.\n\nAll eyes are now on Tuesday, when votes will be counted for the 543 elected seats in the lower house of Parliament. As India uses electronic voting machines, results are expected the same day.\n\nThe elections will test the popularity of Modi, 73, whose image as a strong leader and champion of Hindu nationalism has been bolstered by a series of welfare measures benefiting tens of millions of poor people during his decade in power.\n\nThe BJP's campaign was dominated by the Indian leader, who crisscrossed the country holding more than 200 rallies.\n\nBefore the elections began, the BJP was expected to achieve an easy victory. The party had set itself the goal of winning a qualified majority by winning 400 seats.\n\nAccording to exit polls broadcast by several television networks, the party and its allies could win 350 seats or more, far ahead of the 272 needed for a simple majority. This would give Modi a rare third consecutive term.\n\n\"This is a litmus test for Mr. Modi. When the elections began, it seemed to be a one-horse race. He appeared very invincible, very formidable and set the bar very high,\" according to the political analyst Rasheed Kidwai.\n\nMany observers had expected an opposition alliance of more than two dozen parties that would prevent Modi from reducing his party's huge parliamentary majority, but exit polls predicted it would not be able to do so and showed that the alliance was behind by around 150 seats. However, in this vast and diverse country, exit polls have not always been reliable.\n\n\"The final figures will depend on whether the BJP can hold on in the populous northern states where the party has had huge successes in the past,\" said analyst Kidwai.\n\nAfter polling stations closed on Saturday, Modi thanked voters and said he was convinced that \"the people of India voted in record numbers\" to re-elect the government.\n\nHis comments came after he completed two days of meditation in the southern tip of India, at a memorial to Hindu philosopher Swami Vivekananda. Images released by his party showed him dressed in a saffron-colored robe, with his eyes closed and a rosary in his hand.\n\nThe opposition's hopes of making gains hinge on exploiting growing resentment over high unemployment facing the country's huge young population and rising prices.\n\nCongress Party leader Rahul Gandhi, who was the face of the opposition campaign, focused his campaign on the need to create jobs and increase wealth inequality in the country and said policies government had favored the rich at the expense of the poor. The party promised cash transfers to poor women and an apprenticeship guarantee for university graduates. It has also raised concerns about democratic backsliding under Modi.\n\nThe Congress Party has been marginalized over the past decade while the BJP has emerged as a formidable political force under Modi. It only holds 52 seats in Parliament.\n\n\"A lot will depend on how the Congress Party and its allies fare in key states like Maharashtra in the west, Bihar in the east and Karnataka in the south,\" according to Kidwai.\n\nThe opposition faces a daunting task. To make significant progress, the BJP would also need to do well in the populous northern states, where the BJP is well established and where its Hindu nationalist agenda resonates most. The BJP, for its part, hopes to extend its influence in certain southern states where it has almost no presence.\n\nThe election campaign has been called one of the most controversial in India. At the rallies, Modi accused the Congress Party of being pro-Muslim and planning to grant Muslims benefits reserved for lower-caste Hindus if elected. Analysts said the polarizing rhetoric was an attempt to shore up support from his Hindu base after the vote. got off to a poor start last month.\n\nIn a letter to Punjab voters on Thursday, former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh accused Modi of indulging in \"the most vicious form of hate speech, purely divisive in nature\" during the campaign and accused him to undermine the dignity of the Prime Minister's office. .\n\nPunjab was among seven states and one federal territory that voted on Saturday.\n\nOnly India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, won a third consecutive term. The winning party is expected to form the next government by mid-June, before the end of the current legislature.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"},
