{"uri": "8160886525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:19:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:19:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:18:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2728915/", "title": "Narendra Modi on track to win India elections with weakened mandate - ExBulletin", "body": "Roula Khalaf, editor-in-chief of the FT, selects her favorite stories in this weekly newsletter.\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is poised to win a historic third term, but early vote counts Tuesday suggest his Bharatiya Janata Party and its partners would have a smaller majority than expected.\n\nAs of early Tuesday afternoon, the BJP and its National Democratic Alliance allies were leading with at least 294 of the 543 seats in India's lower house, securing a third five-year term and to form the next government.\n\nEarly trends showed that the opposition INDIA alliance, led by the BJP's main rival, the Indian National Congress, performed better than expected, winning 231 seats.\n\nThe prospect of a reduced majority for the ruling party, which would make it harder to implement economic policy and make Modi more beholden to his smaller allies, has prompted a sharp sell-off in Indian stocks, infrastructure groups and defense leading the losses.\n\nThe benchmark Nifty 50 index fell 8.5%, temporarily erasing its gains for the year, after hitting a record high on Monday following exit polls that indicated Modi would comfortably win the election.\n\nThe early vote count came as a shock to markets, according to Amit Khurana, head of equities at Dolat Capital Market in Mumbai. Assuming the BJP has less than a majority [on its own]this obviously leads to a lot of speculation about room for maneuver [Modi] must lead the government.\n\nExit polls released over the weekend after voting concluded suggested Modi would comfortably win the election, projecting the ruling alliance to win between 353 and 401 seats. During the campaign, Modi and the BJP predicted that the NDA would win as many as 400 seats.\n\nIf the numbers don't change, it's a return to the alliance politics that characterized India from 1989 to 2014, said Pratap Bhanu Mehta, a senior fellow at the Center for Policy Research in New Delhi. In this sense, a much more negotiated government will be required.\n\nMehta added: I'm not sure businesses will like it.\n\nInfrastructure, a crucial policy initiative of the BJP, led the sell-off, with shares of Adani Ports, Adani Enterprises and Oil and Natural Gas Corporation falling 25 per cent, 25 per cent and 21.5 per cent respectively.\n\nMany Indians expected a clear victory for Modi in an election seen as a referendum on his decade in power and at the end of a campaign largely focused on the personality of the 73-year-old prime minister. A victory would make him the first Indian prime minister to serve three consecutive terms since independence leader Jawaharlal Nehru.\n\nGovernment officials had announced an ambitious program of economic reforms for a third term. India has been one of the world's fastest growing economies since the end of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the Prime Minister had expressed his aim of becoming the world's third largest economy, from the current fifth, during of his third term in office and a developed economy by 2047, the centenary of independence.\n\nBut job creation has failed to keep pace with new entrants to the labor market, and Tuesday's early voting trends showed that the BJP is on track to fall short of a parliamentary majority on its own. 272 votes he received during Modi's first two terms.\n\nThe party is also expected to lose some seats in its political stronghold in the Hindi-speaking north, notably in the most populous state of Uttar Pradesh.\n\nIn 10 years, we have become accustomed to a stable government, Swapan Dasgupta, a right-wing commentator, told Indian channel CNN-News18. The current trend in voting results, he said, augurs instability in the country. [NDA] exemption.\n\nFinal results are expected Tuesday evening or Wednesday morning. The results are the culmination of a six-week staggered voting process that began in April.\n\nIn India, voting is taking place in stages due to logistical and security challenges in a country of more than 1.4 billion people. The Election Commission of India said 642 million voters out of nearly a billion registered voters had cast their ballots.\n\nThe result will strengthen the Congress, which was widely seen as a political force in decline after losing seats in India's previous two polls.\n\nBefore the vote, some opposition figures had questioned the integrity of India's electronic voting machines and accused the Modi government of pre-poll repression, after some Congress bank accounts were frozen and two senior figures in the opposition have been imprisoned as part of corruption investigations.\n\nHowever, some commentators saw Tuesday's result as proof that Indian voters were still free to exercise their will.\n\nIndian democracy is not in danger, and I don't think the institutions have been captured as the opposition claimed, said Sugata Srinivasaraju, author and journalist. It will likely be a weakened Modi moving towards a coalition, but we don't have the final results yet.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-04/indias-modi-set-for-a-record-third-term-but-wings-clipped", "title": "India's Modi Set for a Record Third Term, but Wings Clipped", "body": "By Sanjeev Miglani, Charlotte Greenfield and Shivangi Acharya\n\nNEW DELHI (Reuters) - Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi was set for a historic third term on Tuesday, but with a vastly diminished majority in a rare electoral setback for a leader who has held a tight grip on the nation's politics.\n\nModi's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) lost its own majority in parliament for the first time in a decade and is dependent on its regional allies to get past the half-way mark required to run the world's largest democracy.\n\nFor Modi whose approval ratings have been the highest among world leaders and who ran a presidential-style campaign, such a result is the first sign of the ground shifting.\n\n\"For the BJP to drop below the majority mark, this is a personal setback for him,\" said Yogendra Yadav, a psephologist and the founder of a small political group opposed to the BJP.\n\nSince he took power 10 years ago, riding his Hindu nationalist base, Modi has been the ruling alliance's unquestioned leader, with concerns growing about what his opponents see as the country's slide towards authoritarianism.\n\nThe man who as a boy sold tea in his home state of Gujarat has dominated India's politics so completely in the last decade that few in his party or even the parent ideological group, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, dare stand up to him.\n\nIndeed, throughout the campaign in scorching heat, it was Modi with his thinning white hair, a neatly trimmed white beard and immaculate Indian attire who towered over everyone else.\n\nHis giant cutouts were everywhere, his face on television screens every day as he courted India's 968 million voters with a personal \"Modi guarantee\" to change their lives.\n\n\"My sole issue with Modi today is that he has become larger than the party itself,\" said Surendra Kumar Dwivedi, a former head of the Department of Political Science at Lucknow University \"In a democratic system... a party should always supersede an individual.\"\n\n'LAST 10 YEARS IS ONLY A PREVIEW'\n\nStill, Modi will be only the second leader to win a third term after founding prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru and has promised a transformative next five years.\n\nUnder him, India has become the world's fastest growing major economy and he has said he wants to make it the world's third largest in three years, behind the United States and China.\n\n\"What we have done in the last 10 years is only a preview, a trailer,\" Modi told a recent rally. \"We have a lot more to do. Modi is taking the country to a different level in the world.\"\n\nThe BJP has dismissed opposition speculation that Modi, 73, might hang up his boots once he reaches 75, like some other party leaders have done in recent years. Modi has said he wants to lay the groundwork for India to become a fully developed nation by 2047, the 100th year of independence from British colonial rule.\n\n\"Modi will now probably enter in what I call the legacy phase of his prime ministership, driving India forward politically, economically, diplomatically and even militarily,\" said Bilveer Singh, deputy head, department of political science, at the National University of Singapore.\n\nThe idea would be to make the country a \"strong regional power that is also a counterbalance to China, but not to serve Western interest as is sometimes alleged, but mainly to promote India's interest, power and place in international politics\".\n\nA reduced mandate for Modi's ruling alliance forecloses the possibility of changes to India's secular constitution that opposition groups had warned against. Any such measures require the support of two-thirds of members of parliament.\n\nConcerns have grown in recent years that the BJP's Hindu nationalist agenda has polarised the country with Modi himself turning up the rhetoric, accusing the main opposition Congress of appeasing Muslims for votes.\n\nYashwant Deshmukh, founder of CVoter polling agency and a political analyst, said the BJP's top goal of introducing common civil laws to replace Islam's sharia-based customs and other religious codes would have to go on the back burner.\n\n\"These will have to be debated,\" he said.\n\n(Reporting by Shivangi Acharya, Rupam Jain and Krishna N. {"uri": "2024-06-378479629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:45:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:45:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-04/key-moments-in-indias-election", "title": "Key Moments in India's Election", "body": "NEW DELHI (Reuters) - As India counts over 640 million votes in the world's largest election that began on April 19, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance looks set to clinch a majority but his party was unlikely to win on its own, the running vote count showed.\n\nPeople came out in record high temperatures to elect the 543 members of the lower house of the Indian Parliament.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) faced a joint opposition alliance of over two dozen political parties, called the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, or INDIA.\n\nThese are the key political moments that contributed to the result.\n\nJan 22: Modi leads the consecration of a controversial but grand temple to Lord Ram at a bitterly contested site, resulting in a wave of religious fervour that heavily favoured his Hindu nationalist BJP.\n\nJan 31: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman presents an austere budget in an election year, projecting confidence that the Modi-led government would return to power.\n\nFeb 16: Congress, the main opposition party, said the tax department had frozen its bank accounts for a five-year-old demand for $25 million. It later got relief from the Supreme Court.\n\nMarch 14: Data revealed by the poll watchdog showed that business houses Vedanta, Airtel and Essel were among the top funders of political parties through a mechanism that allowed individuals and companies to anonymously donate money to political parties until it was scrapped by the top court.\n\nModi's BJP had garnered most of the money through this route since 2018, when it was introduced, bringing focus to the vast difference in its war chest compared to its opponents.\n\nMarch 16: The poll watchdog, the Election Commission of India, announced the world's largest election with nearly a billion registered voters would kick off on April 19.\n\nPeople would vote in seven phases over a six-week period.\n\nModi said he was confident of a victory, a claim backed by poll predictions. His party leaders said the ruling alliance would win 400 of the 543 seats in parliament's lower house.\n\nMarch 22: Less than a week after the election was announced, India's financial crime fighting agency, the Enforcement Directorate, arrested the chief minister of the capital Delhi, Arvind Kejriwal, one of the key faces of the united opposition.\n\nThis was the latest in a wave of detentions, raids and questioning of opposition politicians by India's investigative agencies.\n\nApril 19: Voting begins, with jobs, inflation, India's rising global profile and Hindu pride as key issues.\n\nApril 21: A lower voter turnout than at the previous election in 2019 worried the BJP, and Modi changed tack in his campaign speeches.\n\nFrom largely focusing on his government's performance on economic development and welfare schemes earlier, Modi accused Congress of planning to redistribute wealth from majority Hindus to minority Muslims.\n\nApril 25: As the campaign turned more acrimonious, the Congress and the BJP complained to the Election Commission about divisive speeches by each other's leaders. The watchdog sought responses from both sides.\n\nAfter a long delay, which the opposition said allowed Modi to further violate the poll code, it asked both sides to show restraint.\n\nMay 10: Halfway through the election, Kejriwal was given bail and allowed to campaign, boosting the opposition.\n\nIn one of his first speeches, Kejriwal raised doubts whether 73-year-old Modi would continue to be the prime minister after turning 75, an age limit the BJP has spoken about in the past.\n\nTop BJP leaders said the party has no such age limit rule, though.\n\nTo counter voter fatigue and resistance from a resurgent opposition, BJP's ideological parent, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh stepped in to help Modi's campaign.\n\nJune 1: Voting ended, with Modi's constituency, Varanasi among the 57 in the last phase.\n\nExit polls, prohibited while voting was on, predicted the BJP would record a thumping win, possibly surpassing its 2019 tally of 303 seats.\n\nJune 4: Counting and result.\n\n(Reporting by Krishn Kaushik; Editing by Raju Gopalakrishnan)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8161545100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:25:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/c715fa47-fb26-401e-8453-ba10f41a71b2", "title": "India election strips Narendra Modi of his 'aura of invincibility'", "body": "As votes from India's six-week long general election were counted on Tuesday, it was quickly clear that Narendra Modi was on course for his third term as prime minister. That is where his satisfaction will end.\n\nThe early results also showed Modi's Bharatiya Janata party set to lose its majority for the first time since 2014 -- a stunning blow to the authority of India's strongest leader in decades and one that would leave him dependent on junior partners in his National Democratic Alliance to govern.\n\nOn Tuesday night, the NDA was ahead in 291 of 543 seats in India's lower house of parliament, far below the more than 350 it held before the vote and the 400 that Modi had set as its target. A motley coalition of anti-BJP opposition parties, known by its acronym INDIA, was on track to nearly double its tally to 234.\n\nConfirmation of the shock result would leave Modi in a weakened position from which to tackle the enormous economic challenges facing India and to undertake the difficult reforms needed to help the world's most populous country secure its status as a rising global power.\n\nModi had lost his \"aura of invincibility\", said Ronojoy Sen, a political scientist at the National University of Singapore.\n\n\"The knives won't be out but\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009Modi's standing within and outside the party [could] take a beating,\" he said, adding that the BJP's coalition partners would \"take their pound of flesh\".\n\nBefore the results, Modi's government had exuded confidence. At his final campaign rally last week, the prime minister crowed prematurely about scoring a \"hat trick\" of absolute majorities in three successive elections. Exit polls published at the weekend also predicted a resounding victory.\n\nModi brushed off concerns about the result on Tuesday night. \"Our opponents together have not won as many seats as the BJP alone has won,\" he told a crowd of supporters, referring to the roughly 240 seats where the ruling party was in the lead in partial counts. \"The country will write a new chapter with many big decisions in the third term.\"\n\nInternational banks and investors, who have placed bets on India as a pivotal \"China plus one\" economy and growing consumer market, will be keenly watching how durable a coalition government Modi can build.\n\nModi has sold himself to both the Indian public and overseas investors as a strong, decisive leader capable of enacting tough reform and maintaining stable government. But analysts warned that reliance on its NDA partners, which include several smaller regional parties, could force the BJP into concessions such as offering them ministerial posts and dropping politically unpopular reforms.\n\nThe early results triggered a sharp sell-off in Indian equities on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nifty 50 stock index falling 6 per cent.\n\nEmkay Global, a brokerage, warned in a client note that key parts of the BJP's reform agenda, including privatisation and the kinds of labour and land market reforms demanded by foreign manufacturers, would be \"off the table\" if the loss of its majority was confirmed.\n\nShumita Deveshwar, an economist at GlobalData. TSLombard, warned that coalition politics could force the BJP -- which has touted its responsible fiscal policies to foreign investors -- into \"competitive populism\".\n\n\"Any whiff of political volatility makes the markets nervous,\" she said. \"The markets see that if the BJP doesn't have a majority then passing reforms through parliament will be harder\".\n\nBoth the BJP and the INDIA alliance may now seek to shift the balance of power by inducing rival members of parliament to defect to their sides.\n\n\"It will be back to pre-2014\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009There will be the compulsions of coalition politics,\" said Seshadri Chari, a pro-BJP commentator. But he added that the prime minister knew the \"art of management\"\n\n\"Politics is all about management. I don't see any difficulty as far as Modi is concerned in handling the situation,\" Chari said.\n\nModi went into the election, which ran from April to June 1, enjoying high popularity thanks to his potent blend of Hindu nationalist politics, economic reforms supportive of big business, and development spending.\n\nHis government has spoken of building a $10tn economy by the mid-2030s, more than twice its current size, and vowed to lift the country to developed-economy status by 2047.\n\nBut analysts said Modi appeared to have miscalculated the depth of anti-incumbency feeling and economic dissatisfaction. The BJP seemed to struggle on the campaign trail as the opposition seized on India's widening inequality.\n\nModi, who has been unable to effectively address widespread joblessness despite rapid economic growth, responded by doubling down on polarising religious rhetoric about India's Muslim minority. But the margin of the prime minister's victory even in his own constituency of Varanasi was on Tuesday on track to fall from past elections.\n\nThe Indian National Congress, the BJP's main rival, ran on a platform of boosting welfare spending and creating more government jobs.\n\n\"I am happy with the verdict,\" said Sumit Kumar, a 22-year-old jobseeker in Delhi. \"I did not vote for Modi because he could not give jobs to the youth.\"\n\nBut some foreign investors were optimistic about Modi's prospects. \"I do not expect Modi to change his policies,\" said Alessia Berardi, head of emerging macro strategy at the research arm of European asset manager Amundi. \"Even continuing with what we had so far, I think that is good for investors, and for business.\"", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", {"uri": "8160617331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:30:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:30:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T07:29:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/india-election-narendra-modis-bjp-071342831.html", "title": "India election: Narendra Modi's BJP leads main rival in early vote counting", "body": "Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance raced to a majority in the general election in early vote counting trends on Tuesday, but the numbers appeared well short of the landslide predicted in exit polls.\n\nIndia began counting more than 640 million votes on Tuesday in the world's biggest election, which was widely expected to return Prime Minister Modi to a third term after a decade in power.\n\nExit polls on June 1 had projected Mr Modi and his Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would register a big victory, with its National Democratic Alliance (NDA) seen getting a two-thirds majority and more.\n\nBy 7am on Tuesday in the UK, TV channels showed the NDA was ahead in nearly 300 of the 543 elective seats in parliament, where 272 is a simple majority, in early counting.\n\nBut the opposition INDIA alliance, led by Rahul Gandhi's centrist Congress party, was performing better than expected and leading in more than 220 seats.\n\nTV channels showed BJP accounted for nearly 250 of the seats in which the NDA was leading, short of a majority on its own, compared to the 303 it won in 2019.\n\nA third Modi term with a slim majority for BJP - or having to depend on NDA allies for a majority - could introduce some uncertainty into governance as Mr Modi has ruled with an authoritative hold over the government in the last decade.\n\nHowever, politicians and analysts said it was too early to get a firm idea of the voting trends since a majority of ballots were yet to be counted.\n\nThe early see-saw trends spooked markets with stocks falling steeply, while the rupee also fell sharply against the dollar.\n\nThe markets had soared on Monday after exit polls on June 1 projected a landslide win for Mr Modi.\n\n\"It's a fair assessment to say 400 at the moment certainly looks distant,\" BJP spokesperson Nalin Kohli told the India Today TV channel early on Tuesday, referring to some projections that gave 400 seats to the NDA.\n\n\"But we need to wait...to have a final picture of the seats because the exit polls speak of a massive sweep, (and) the counting trends currently don't seem to match that,\" he said.\n\n\"The BJP-NDA will form the government, that trend is very clear from the start,\" he added.\n\nExit polls have often got election outcomes wrong in India. Nearly one billion people were registered to vote, of which 642 million turned out.\n\nHowever, if Modi's victory is confirmed even by a slim margin, his BJP will have triumphed in a vitriolic campaign in which parties accused each other of religious bias and of posing a threat to sections of the population.\n\nThe Indian votes were being counted as election fever swept other major nations.\n\nIn the US, newly convicted former president Donald Trump and incumbent Joe Biden are on the campaign trail as they prepare to go head-to-head on November 5.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8161422736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:57:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:57:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:56:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/asia/the-latest-india-counts-votes-from-a-mega-election-as-modi-claims-victory-for-his/article_e5392562-e970-576e-8729-a8886484e25d.html", "title": "The Latest | India counts votes from a mega-election as Modi claims victory for his alliance", "body": "NEW DELHI (AP) -- India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed victory for his alliance on Tuesday as early results from the staggered, six-week election showed fewer seats for the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party than expected and it appeared unlikely to secure a majority on its own.\n\n\"Today's victory is the victory of the world's largest democracy\" Modi told a crowd at his party's headquarters. He said his National Democratic Alliance will form the government for the third consecutive time.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nBJP is part of the National Democratic Alliance, which so far had won 67 seats, 62 of them going to BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which so far had won 31 seats, 27 of them for Congress.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in the 543-seat Parliament.\n\nNearly 970 million people -- more than 10% of the world's population -- were eligible to vote and turnout averaged 66%, according to official data. The tallying at counting centers in 543 constituencies could stretch well into the evening before final results are announced, though substantial leads are likely to emerge earlier.\n\nIndia's vote is the latest in an unusually busy stretch of elections around the world that are challenging the status quo.\n\nCurrently:\n\n-- What to know as votes are being counted.\n\n-- The world's largest election, in photos.\n\n-- Voting ended Saturday in the election that's a referendum on Modi's decade in power.\n\n-- A scorching heat wave killed 14 in India before the final phase of voting.\n\n-- Modi touts India's roaring economy, but many feel left behind.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nMODI SAYS INDIA WILL SEE 'A NEW CHAPTER OF BIG DECISIONS'\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi says India will will see a \"new chapter of big decisions\" in his third term in office.\n\nAfter claiming victory for his coalition alliance despite a lacklustre performance from his own party, Modi told a crowd at party headquarters he would not shirk from pushing forward with his agenda.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHe said he would advance India's defense production, jobs for youth, raise exports and help farmers, among other things.\n\n\"This country will see a new chapter of big decisions. This is Modi's guarantee,\" he said, speaking in the third person.\n\nBJP FACING MAJOR UPSET IN UTTAR PRADESH\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party is facing a major upset in India's most populous state of Uttar Pradesh at the hands of a powerful regional group, Samajwadi Party, or Socialist Group.\n\nThe Samajwadi Party, led my Akhilesh Yadav, already had won 10 seats and was leading in another 28 seats. Its ally, the Congress party, won four seats and was leading in another two.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party had won 12 seats and was leading in 20 seats. Exit polls had predicted a landslide victory for BJP in all 80 seats.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nModi was among the winners in the state from the Varanasi constituency. Rahul Gandhi of the Congress party won in his family bastion of Rae Bareli.\n\nIn January, Modi inaugurated a massive temple for Lord Ram in Varanasi.\n\nRajendra Chaudhry, spokesperson for the Samajwadi Party, said: \"In this election, it seems Lord Ram has deserted the BJP.\"\n\nThe Samajwadi Party was founded in 1992 by Mulayam Singh Yadav, who served as its top elected official for several years. His son, Akhilesh Yadav, took over the party leadership after his death.\n\nMODI SAYS HIS COALITION ON THE PATH TO WIN A THIRD TERM\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi says his coalition is on the path to a third straight term in government after India's marathon election.\n\n\"People have placed their faith in NDA, for a third consecutive time! This is a historical feat in India's history,\" Modi said in a post on X, referring to the National Democratic Alliance headed by his party. He said he will continue to work and fulfil the aspirations of the people.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAs Modi posted his comment, his coalition had won 128 seats and led in 157 races, according to the Election Commission. A total of 272 seats are needed to form a majority government.\n\nINDIA'S OPPOSITION SAYS STRONG SHOWING 'A WIN FOR DEMOCRACY'\n\nIndia's opposition Congress party has called its alliance's strong showing in the polls a \"win for democracy\" and a \"moral and political loss\" for Prime Minister Narendra Modi.\n\nCongress party President Mallikarjun Kharge told a news conference in New Delhi that because no party had a clear majority, the mandate was against Modi.\n\n\"Our fight has not ended yet. We will continue to fight for the country's development, for the constitution, for the benefit of the people,\" Kharge said.\n\nModi's coalition led in a majority of seats Tuesday in India's general election, according to early figures, but faced a stronger challenge from the opposition than expected.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRahul Gandhi, the face of the Congress party's campaign, said the results showed India does not want Modi.\n\n\"People's clear message to PM Modi and Home Minister Amit shah is that we don't want you to run the nation,\" Gandhi said. \"The poorest of this country have defended the constitution of India.\"\n\nMODI WINS SEAT IN VARANASI\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi has won a seat in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi, where he ran in 2014 and 2019, India's Election Commission reported.\n\nModi won by more than 152,000 votes and secured 54% of total votes. He ran against the Congress party's Ajai Rai, who got 40%.\n\nVaranasi is located on the banks of the revered Ganges River and is part of Uttar Pradesh state, India's most populous, with around 200 million people.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBJP LOSES SEAT IN AYODHYA, WHERE MODI OPENED A GRAND TEMPLE IN JANUARY\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's party has lost a seat in the Ayodhya constituency, a deeply symbolic loss after he opened a grand but controversial Hindu temple there in January.\n\nThe Bharatiya Janata Party candidate, Lallu Singh, lost to a rival from the regional Samajwadi Party, Singh's poll agent Kamlesh Srivastava told The Associated Press.\n\nModi and his party had campaigned heavily at the temple dedicated to Lord Ram, built on the historic ruins of a mosque that was destroyed by Hindu mobs in 1992.\n\nExperts said the January opening, where Modi performed rituals inside the temple, marked the unofficial start of his campaign as they hoped it would resonate with his Hindu majority voters. Modi's government had turned it into a national event by organizing live screenings across the country and closing offices for half a day.\n\nThe BJP had held a seat in Ayodhya since 2014.\n\nMODI'S PARTY WINS 19, CONGRESS PARTY 4 SEATS IN CONFIRMED RACES\n\nWhile the vote counting is still continuing, results have been called for 28 parliamentary seats out of 542 so far.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party has won 19 seats, according to India's Election Commission, while the main opposition Congress party secured four seats. The rest went to different regional parties.\n\nVote tallying is expected to take all day Tuesday, but the count so far shows Modi's party leading in 224 seats with the Congress ahead in 98.\n\nEARLY TALLIES SHOW MODI'S BJP LEADING IN 25 OF 26 SEATS IN HIS HOME STATE\n\nEarly leads by India's election commission projected Modi's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party was leading in 25 of 26 seats in the prime minister's home state of Gujarat. But party leaders said they were not celebrating victory due to a recent blaze at an amusement park in the state that killed 27 people, including children.\n\nA massive fire broke out in May at an amusement park in the state's Rajkot city.\n\n\"We had decided that there will be no celebratory victory or beating of drums. So we are not celebrating,\" said C. R. Patil, a senior leader from Modi's party.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMODI MAY NEED A COALITION TO KEEP HIS JOB\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling Hindu nationalist party appeared to be falling short of a majority in the early vote count Tuesday. If these trends hold, it would be a stunning setback to the populist prime minister who has never relied on coalition partners to govern.\n\nBharatiya Janata Party is still expected to form the new government and return Modi as the prime minister for a rare third consecutive term as his National Democratic Alliance was leading in about 290 seats. A majority requires 272 seats. BJP alone was leading in 242 seats.\n\nStill, that's not the strong finish Modi was aiming for after his party won landslide victories in the 2014 and 2019 elections.\n\nIf BJP doesn't win a majority on its own, it could \"be heavily dependent on the goodwill of its allies, which makes them critical players who we can expect will extract their pound of flesh, both in terms of policymaking as well as government formation,\" said Milan Vaishnav, director of the South Asia Program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.\n\n\"This would be truly, you know, uncharted territory, both for Indians as well as for the prime minister,\" Vaishnav said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSince coming to power in 2014, Modi's BJP has governed in a coalition government but has always had a majority on its own.\n\nINDIA'S MAIN STOCK INDICES CLOSE SHARPLY DOWN AS EARLY VOTE TALLIES SHOW A CLOSER RACE THAN EXPECTED\n\nAs the early vote count showed Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party facing a tighter than expected race, India's two main benchmark stock indices closed down sharply.\n\nThe NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex had hit new highs at the close of day Monday but dropped sharply Tuesday as the early vote figures started to come in.\n\nThey recovered slightly to each close down more than 5%.\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nEven if Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party does not secure a parliamentary majority on its own, early leads reported by India's Election Commission showed his coalition, which includes smaller parties, still could.\n\nJAILED POLITICIAN WINS NORTHERN BARAMULLA CONSTITUENCY AFTER OPPONENT CONCEDES\n\nA politician from disputed Kashmir who has been in New Delhi's Tihar Jail since 2019 in a terror funding case has won after his rival conceded defeat.\n\nSheikh Abdul Rashid from northern Baramulla constituency won as an independent candidate, beating former chief minister of the region Omar Abdullah.\n\n\"I think it's time to accept the inevitable,\" Abdullah wrote on X. \"I don't believe his victory will hasten his release from prison nor will the people of North Kashmir get the representation they have a right to but the voters have spoken and in a democracy that's all that matters.\"\n\nRashid's campaign was run by his two sons, hoping a win for him would lead to his release from prison. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir, which is divided between the neighbors but claimed by both in its entirety. Modi's government revoked Indian-controlled Kashmir's semi-autonomous status during a 2019 security clampdown.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRebel groups in the region have been fighting against Indian rule since 1989. Tens of thousands of people have been killed in the armed uprising and subsequent Indian military crackdown. The rebels want Kashmir to be united under Pakistani rule or become an independent country.\n\nOPPOSITION SHOWS SURPRISING EARLY LEADS IN UTTAR PRADESH, INDIA'S MOST POPULOUS STATE\n\nIndia's most populous state is showing surprising early leads for the opposition, despite being previously controlled by Modi's Hindu nationalist party.\n\nEarly tallies reported by the Election Commission showed the opposition Congress party and its ally, the Samajwadi Party, were leading on more than half the seats in the crucial northern Uttar Pradesh state ruled by a Hindu monk who is considered a future prime minister candidate by Modi supporters.\n\nUttar Pradesh sends the most lawmakers of any state -- 80 -- to Parliament. It has long been considered the biggest prize in Indian elections. It's also home to Ayodhya, where a Hindu temple was built on the site of a razed mosque.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Samajwadi Party was leading in 35 seats, with Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party ahead in 34 seats. The Congress party was leading in seven seats.\n\nIn the 2019 election, BJP won 62 seats in the state.\n\nMODI'S BJP IS AHEAD IN EARLY TALLIES, BUT WITH A STRONGER OPPOSITION SHOWING THAN EXPECTED\n\nIndia's Election Commission says early counting of votes shows incumbent Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party comfortably ahead, but with a stronger than expected showing by the main opposition.\n\nSome six hours into counting, Modi's Hindu nationalist BJP was ahead in 236 constituencies and had won two -- including one uncontested -- of 543 parliamentary seats.\n\nThe main opposition Congress party was leading in 99 constituencies.\n\nThe Election Commission does not release data on the percentage of votes tallied, but counting is expected to go on through the day. A total of some 642 million votes are being counted in the world's largest democratic exercise.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nModi's party is part of the National Democratic Alliance, whose parties were leading in 283 constituencies according to the early count, including the two won by BJP. The Congress party is part of the INDIA alliance, which was leading in 232 constituencies.\n\nA total of 272 seats are needed for a majority in parliament.\n\nINDIAN MARKETS ARE DOWN SHARPLY AS EARLY TALLIES SHOW A STRONGER CHALLENGE FROM THE OPPOSITION THAN EXPECTED\n\nIndian markets, which closed at an all-time high Monday, were down sharply in midday trading Tuesday, after early leads showed fewer seats for Modi's governing BJP than had been expected.\n\nModi's party still showed a comfortable lead, according to early figures reported by India's election commission. but was facing a stronger challenge from the opposition than exit polls had projected.\n\nIndia's benchmark stock indices, the NIFTY 50 and the BSE Sensex, were both down by more than 8% before recovering slightly. This followed a dip of more than 3% when markets opened.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe country's stock markets have boomed under Modi, whose pro-market policies have made him popular among India's corporations and businesspeople.\n\nWORKERS TAKE HEAT PRECAUTIONS AS VOTES ARE COUNTED IN TEMPERATURES EXPECTED TOO REACH 106F\n\nTemperatures in the Indian capital were down Tuesday from highs in the past week of 45 degrees Celsius (113 degrees Fahrenheit), but election officials and political parties were nonetheless taking precautions as votes were being counted.\n\nWorkers carried cases of water into one air-conditioned counting station in New Delhi early in the morning in preparation, while tents outside for security personnel and others were outfitted with industrial evaporative coolers.\n\nTemperatures in the morning hovered around 37 C (99 F) in New Delhi and were expected to rise to 41 C (106 F) by the end of the day.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt the headquarters of the opposition Congress party, a tent was set up outside, equipped with evaporative coolers, for waiting media.\n\nWOMEN ARE A KEY VOTING BLOC IN INDIA'S 2024 ELECTION\n\nIndian women are a key voting bloc with more of them voting in recent elections than ever before. Most poll experts expect women voters to play a decisive role in determining the 2024 election results.\n\nPolitical parties have been wooing them with monthly cash handouts, subsidized cooking gas cylinders and low-interest loans. Many such programs have particularly helped Modi's Bharatiya Janata party widen its support among them, especially in rural areas. The opposition alliance also tried to gain women's votes by unveiling programs that promised financial aid of $1,200 per year to poor women, and promised to reserve 50% of government jobs for women if voted into power.\n\nWomen make up nearly 49% of India's total electorate. Turnout has grown in each recent major election -- of women who were eligible to vote, 53% voted in 2004; 56% in 2009; 65.5% in 2014; and 67% in 2019. Data for 2024 was not yet available but was estimated to resemble 2019's female voter turnout.\n\nCOUNTING STARTS WITH POSTAL BALLOTS THEN MOVES TO ELECTRONIC ONES\n\nThe counting of some 642 million votes cast in India's election is being done at various locations around the country by government employees. Chief election commissioner Rajiv Kumar said they were starting with postal ballots and then move on to combining the votes from India's electronic voting machines.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe process is expected to be completed by the end of the day Tuesday.\n\nIndia has close to 970 million eligible voters, and votes were cast at more than a million polling stations staggered over the last six weeks.\n\nThat brought the final phase into India's hottest season, with temperatures higher than 45 degrees Celsius (113 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country, and Kumar said the election officials learned a valuable lesson.\n\n\"We should have completed the election at least one month before,\" he said ahead of the start of the counting. \"We shouldn't have let it continue into so much heat.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow AP election coverage at https://apnews.com/hub/global-elections\n\nRead more on the India Election at thestar.com", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", {"uri": "2024-06-377383998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "15:34:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T15:34:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T15:24:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2727631/", "title": "India elections: Prime Minister Narendra Modi could break new ground as exit polls predict unprecedented victory", "body": "Modi's popularity has become the most important theme, despite issues such as unemployment and inflation, said Yashwant Deshmukh, an independent political commentator and founder of research firm C-Voter.\n\nPeople expect Modi to be a better solution provider than Rahul Gandhi or any other opposition leader, he said. There are clear expectations regarding India's growth in terms of economy which has helped.\n\nIf Modi wins a third term, he will equal the record of three terms as prime minister of Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's leader from 1947 to 1964.\n\nThe rising cost of living and unemployment have emerged as key issues in the election, but the discontent does not appear to have damaged Modi's image.\n\nWith the opposition waging its strongest campaign since 2014, independent media on YouTube gaining popularity, and unemployment continuing to be a significant concern for voters, the opposition might rightly have expected good results, said Pratik Dattani, founder of the London-based think tank Bridge. India.\n\nBut it appears that dissatisfaction with the government has not translated into the anger that might be needed to get voters to change their vote.\n\nThis was a referendum on Modi. So voters may have penalized the absence of an opposition prime ministerial candidate, seeing Modi as the best choice for prime minister, Dattani said.\n\nAfter 10 years of BJP rule, the party was bound to suffer from anti-incumbency bias. Even though such sentiments were pervasive among parliamentarians, the BJP probably triumphed by relying on Modi, says Deshmukh.\n\nPeople are extremely disappointed with the sitting MLAs, even the BJP MLAs, but for Modi's sake, they have rejected them, he said.\n\nExit polls indicated that the BJP made significant inroads into southern India as well as eastern India, expanding its influence from its traditional Hindi-speaking regions in the north, central and western India.\n\nIf the exit poll predictions prove correct, it will mean the emergence of the BJP as a national party, no longer confined to the Hindi heartland, said Nilanjan Mukhopadhyay, an independent political commentator.\n\nThis could also mean great support for the idea of Hindutva (Hindu nation) across the country.\n\nThe BJP is expected to win not only in the state of Karnataka, where it is strongest in the southern region, but also in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, according to exit polls.\n\nDeshmukh said the BJP's vote share is also expected to increase in the states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu, which had earlier proved virtually invincible for the party.\n\nIn the eastern state of West Bengal, the BJP appears neck and neck with the influential regional Trinamool Congress party, Deshmukh said.\n\nModis' legacy\n\nThis may be the last term for Modi, 73, who was once a pariah in the Western world due to religious riots during his time as Gujarat chief minister in 2002 that led to the death of 1,000 to 2,000 people. people, mainly Muslims.\n\nBut thanks to India's economic growth, the country is increasingly seen internationally as a geopolitical counterweight to China.\n\nOpposition members have warned that another Modi term could seriously damage India's secular and democratic traditions, arguing that the BJP's Hindu nationalist agenda has polarized the country.\n\nAnother term for Modi will take India further away from democracy. Modi is fighting against the principles on which India was founded in 1947, said Kingshuk Nag, an independent author and political commentator, adding that Modi's grip on power will only grow if he is re-elected.\n\nObservers expect big business to benefit from a BJP victory, although they say industrial development will favor states like Gujarat and Maharashtra, where the ruling party is more popular, compared to others like West Bengal.\n\nStock analysts are also optimistic about India's growth prospects in the event of a return of the Modis government, expecting reforms to develop infrastructure and boost growth in the manufacturing sector.\n\nThis government has finally understood that the manufacturing sector must increase as a percentage of GDP. They have seen it in the way China has behaved over the last 30 to 40 years, said Shekhar Sambhashivan, director of Indian equity investments at investment management firm Invesco.\n\nAlthough the government says it wants this figure to be closer to around a quarter, even if we assume on a conservative basis they would end up at 20 percent of GDP, he said.\n\nThe BJP has said it wants India to become a fully developed nation by 2047, its 100th anniversary of independence from British colonial rule. It also has the ambitious goal of increasing the size of the world's fifth-largest economy eight-fold, to $29 trillion by then, and increasing per capita income seven-fold, to nearly $18,000.\n\nThis vision seems to have appealed to part of the middle class and the poor of India.\n\nIf Modi succeeds in securing a third term, then he will establish a legacy that is difficult to match, says Mukhopadhyay.\n\nThis would be unprecedented. Nehru benefited from the legacy of the national movement against British rule to help him get elected. {"uri": "8158604581", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "04:01:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T04:01:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T04:00:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/03/india-election-results-exit-polls-narendra-modi-victory", "title": "India elections: exit polls show Narendra Modi expected to win historic third term", "body": "Modi's ruling BJP may gain a two-thirds majority, amid allegations of intimidation of opposition candidates and Muslim voter suppression\n\nVoting has come to a close in India's mammoth elections, as exit polls widely predicted prime minister Narendra Modi would win a historic third term in proceedings marred by allegations of irregularities.\n\nThe election, the longest and largest in India's history with almost a billion eligible voters, began in mid-April. As it progressed over seven phases until 1 June, a deadly heatwave gripped the country, with temperatures almost touching 50C in areas, leading to deaths of dozens of voters and polling officials.\n\nCounting begins at 8am on Tuesday, and results are expected the same day. Vote counting is done simultaneously at counting stations in each of the 543 constituencies around the country.\n\nAccording to a flurry of exit polls released on Saturday night, Modi and his Bharatiya Janata party (BJP) are looking at a decisive win and may even gain seats to win a two-thirds majority in parliament, which would allow the government to make far-reaching amendments to the constitution.\n\nIt would be a historic achievement for Modi, India's strongman prime minister, whose Hindu nationalist politics have significantly re-shaped India's secular democracy over the past decade. No prime minister since Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first post-independence premier, has won three consecutive terms.\n\nAs the election unfolded, allegations of irregularities by the BJP began emerge. Opponents alleged the BJP was undermining India's democratic processes through the harassment and intimidation of opposition candidates and parties and suppression of Muslim voters who are not the BJP's usual vote bank. BJP leaders, including the prime minister himself, were accused of openly violating election rules as they resorted to polarising anti-Muslim rhetoric on the campaign trail.\n\nOpposition parties also accused the BJP of using state machinery to go after them, including the arrest of senior opposition figures and the freezing of the funds of the Congress party by the tax authorities.\n\nUS thinktank Freedom House said this year the BJP had \"increasingly used government institutions to target political opponents\".\n\nOn Sunday, Arwind Kejriwal, one of the most prominent opposition leaders and the chief minister of Delhi, was returned to jail after briefly being released on a temporary bail in order to campaign in the elections. Kejriwal has alleged the corruption case against him is \"politically motivated\" by the Modi government in order to undermine his party, a charge the BJP denies.\n\nRahul Gandhi, the most prominent member of the opposition's once-formidable Congress party and scion of a dynasty that dominated Indian politics for decades, was convicted of criminal libel last year after a complaint by a member of Modi's party.\n\nHis two-year prison sentence saw him disqualified from parliament until the verdict was suspended by a higher court and raised concerns over democratic norms.\n\nHemant Soren, the former chief minister of the eastern state of Jharkhand, was also arrested in February in a separate corruption probe.\n\nKejriwal, Rahul Gandhi and Soren are all members of an opposition alliance composed of more than two dozen parties, but the bloc has struggled to make inroads against Modi. According to predictions, the alliance, which includes the Congress party, will get just only 125 to 165 seats out of 543.\n\nModi was widely seen as a frontrunner even before elections began. Over his ten years as prime minister, the cult of personality around him has grown while his power has become deeply entrenched. Several exit polls suggested that the BJP's dominance would increase further this time, with gains in southern states such as Tamil Nadu and eastern states such as West Bengal, where the party had previously struggled to gain strong support due to regional opposition.\n\n\"On one very basic level, the election didn't matter,\" said Neelanjan Sircar, a senior fellow at the Centre for Policy Research in Delhi. \"The dominant view was always that Modi and the BJP are coming back, irrespective of the numbers. The bigger question mark is: what genuine democratic legitimacy will be derived from this election?\"\n\nIndia's opposition sought to dismiss the exit poll projections, which they described as \"bogus\" and \"fraudulent\" and alleged they were deliberate attempts to justify rigging of the elections.\n\nThe mainstream media is seen to have been brought under the thumb of the BJP government and predominately pro-Modi narratives were broadcast during the campaign, including dozens of fawning interviews with the prime minister where he proclaimed several times to have been chosen by God.\n\nYet analysts warned that that the one-sided media narrative and election being seen as fait accompli before campaigning even began had led to a growing mistrust in the electoral system among the public. During the campaign, the election commission - the body tasked with regulating polls - was among those widely accused of being \"spineless\" and no longer a neutral observer after it ignored repeated calls to hold Modi and the BJP account for repeated alleged violations of election rules.\n\nOne of the most prominent figures vocalising these frustrations over the campaign was Dhruv Rathee, an Indian YouTuber whose videos criticising the Modi government and alleging an erosion of India's democratic processes have earned him 21 million subscribers, far outreaching Modi's social media presence.\n\nRathee has been releasing political commentary videos since 2017 but over the course of the election he rose to become a household name as one of the few who dared to voice dissent.\n\n\"This is the least fair election in India's history,\" said Rathee from Germany, where he now lives. \"Opposition leaders have been put in jail, anyone who stands up to the BJP is harassed by the state or by police and the BJP has been given free rein to violate all the election rules and stir up hatred. There's nothing fair about it.\"\n\nAs campaigning came to a close, Modi - who had appeared at over 200 rallies over the course of campaigning - took himself on a 45-hour meditation retreat at a spiritual site in Tamil Nadu. Though it was said to be in isolation, hundreds of tv cameras were present and it was broadcast live across 24 hour news channels.\n\n\"Sources\" told right wing media that the prime minister would be surviving on a liquid-only diet of coconut water and grape juice.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-377665297", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:19:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:19:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.wsiltv.com/news/consumer/who-will-lead-india-world-s-largest-nation-begins-a-mammoth-day-of-vote-counting/article_a38ceda5-b560-56e3-b261-dcf60baad152.html", "title": "Who will lead India? World's largest nation begins a mammoth day of vote counting after weeks-long election", "body": "(CNN) -- Hundreds of millions of votes cast, more than six weeks of polling, and billions of dollars spent: India on Tuesday will declare a new leader after a mammoth nationwide election that has become a referendum on the last decade of leadership by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.\n\nHis powerful right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is seeking a supermajority in the lower house of parliament - or Lok Sabha - a goal which, if successful, would give it an unstoppable mandate to further enshrine its Hindu-nationalist agenda, deepening India's move away from its secular foundations.\n\nGiven India's strategic position in Asia and its booming economy, the election result will reverberate far beyond its borders, capturing the attention of the United States, China and Russia in particular.\n\nSome 642 million people cast their vote in the world's largest election, as swathes of the country was blanketed in searing heat, making people sick and killing dozens.\n\nHoping to unseat India's charismatic but divisive leader is an alliance of more than two dozen parties, including the country's main opposition, the Indian National Congress, which is running on a platform of reducing inequality and upholding democratic institutions which it argues are at risk.\n\nSince assuming power in 2014, Modi has attained levels of popularity not seen in decades, owing to a raft of development and welfare programs, mixed with a strident brand of Hindu nationalism in a country where about 80% of the population are followers of the polytheistic faith.\n\nUnder Modi's leadership, the country of 1.4 billion people has become the world's fastest-growing major economy and a modern global power, making strides in technology and space. Yet, despite these successes, poverty and youth unemployment persist - particularly in rural areas - and the wealth gap has widened.\n\nCritics also say a decade of Modi's governance has led to growing religious polarization, with Islamophobia marginalizing much of the country's more than 200 million Muslims, and religious violence flaring up in a nation with a long history of communal tensions.\n\nPolling began on April 19 and ended on June 1. Nearly 1 billion Indians were eligible to vote for 543 seats in the lower house of parliament. The leader of the party that wins a majority will become prime minister and form a ruling government.\n\nModi has set an ambitious target of securing a 400-seat supermajority, with 370 directly controlled by his BJP - up from 303 in 2019 - and the others from its National Democratic Alliance.\n\nHis BJP centered its manifesto on job creation and anti-poverty programs, with a focus on women, the poor and farmers. He's promised to turn India into a developed nation by 2047 and transform the country into a global manufacturing hub.\n\nYet, on the campaign trail, he has been accused of deploying openly divisive rhetoric that has been condemned as Islamophobic, while casting himself as an instrument chosen by God.\n\nModi sparked a row over hate speech when he accused Muslims - who have been part of India for centuries - of being \"infiltrators,\" and echoing a false conspiracy voiced by some Hindu nationalists that Muslims are displacing the country's Hindu population by deliberately having large families. His BJP released several political videos targeting Muslims, one of which is under investigation by police.\n\nCongress has governed India for much of its independent history, having been instrumental in ending nearly 200 years of British colonial rule. But over the last decade, it has struggled to find relevance - partly due to a series of corruption scandals and infighting - unable to break through Modi's popularity.\n\nRahul Gandhi, the son of the famed Gandhi dynasty, is the face of the party but lost the past two elections to Modi. He is contending once again from the southern state of Kerala and the crucial state of Uttar Pradesh in the north, also India's most populous.\n\nOpposition leaders and parties have faced a slew of legal and financial challenges in the run-up to this year's election, with many accusing the BJP of using state agencies to stifle opponents.\n\nThe arrest in March of the popular Aam Aadmi Party leader, chief minister of Delhi and staunch Modi critic Arvind Kejriwal sparked protests in the capital and prompted claims of a political \"conspiracy\" by his party - claims the BJP has denied.\n\nKejriwal's release on interim bail last month galvanized the opposition to put up a tough fight against the BJP, uniting a group of political leaders who were once divided over ideological differences.\n\nThe Congress' manifesto has also been dubbed one of India's most progressive, pledging \"freedom from fear\" and vowing to protect freedom of speech, expression and religious belief espoused in the constitution.\n\nTurnout across all seven phases has slightly dipped from the record highs of 2019, yet India's general election remains the largest exercise in democracy, with hundreds of millions showing up to determine who will lead the world's most populous country.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8160609359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "07:24:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T07:24:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T07:23:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/india-election-results-narendra-modi-rcna154839", "title": "Modi's alliance has early lead in India election vote count", "body": "VARANASI, India -- Early vote counting suggests Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will win a rare third term on Tuesday, entering a new decade as leader of the world's most populous country at a time when India is growing closer to the U.S. and gaining clout around the world.\n\nModi enjoys wide support both at home and among the large Indian diaspora in the U.S. and elsewhere, with voters rewarding a leader they see as responsible for India's rocketing economy and rising confidence on the world stage. According to Morning Consult, Modi is by far the world's most popular leader, with an approval rating of 74%.\n\nHis Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and allied parties appeared to have secured almost 300 of 543 seats in Parliament, according to early results, giving them a simple majority. But the opposition was doing better than expected in an election that exit polls had suggested Modi's alliance would win by a landslide.\n\nBut critics say Modi has also eroded human rights in India, the world's largest democracy, and stoked religious tensions, particularly against India's Muslim minority, with Modi and other BJP candidates accused of hate speech and other inflammatory rhetoric during the campaign. India is also struggling to provide enough jobs for its 1.4 billion people, despite being the world's fastest-growing major economy.\n\nModi's ethos of a Hindu-first nation is now deeply entrenched in Indian politics, raising fears among Muslims and other minority groups over how they will fare during five more years of Modi rule.\n\nIn Modi's home seat of Varanasi, which voted Saturday in the last of seven phases of voting, Tasneem Fatma walked out of a polling station wearing a burqa, saying, \"We want a united India, not for Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Isai.\"\n\nBut Fatma, 20, a business student, was interrupted by an older man who said there was no religious divide. He also dismissed Fatma's concerns about unemployment, saying, \"If you are educated and if you are capable of the job, you can take the job.\"\n\nAs the discussion grew more heated, police officers asked the man to leave before NBC News could ask for his name.\n\nIndia's election is considered the world's largest, with nearly a billion registered voters and polling that spanned over six weeks. But it was not just the sheer size of the election that posed a challenge for officials.\n\nVoting has taken place amid unusually high temperatures that have exceeded 120 degrees in New Delhi, the capital, and experts say that may have depressed turnout. At least 33 people in three states died of suspected heatstroke just on Friday, Reuters reported, including election officials who were on duty.\n\nAlthough Indian summers are generally hot, scientists say heat waves in India and elsewhere in South Asia are becoming hotter, longer and more frequent at least partly as a result of climate change. Neither the BJP nor the opposition has said much about climate change during the campaign.\n\nThe issue foremost in the minds of voters who spoke with NBC News was jobs. It's an especially big worry for those ages 15 to 29, who make up 83% of unemployed people in India, according to a report in March.\n\n\"Why is nobody talking about rising costs or lack of jobs or poor kids dying or trees being cut?\" Fatma asked.\n\nIndia's opposition parties, led by the Indian National Congress, have tried to use such issues to drive voters away from Modi. Aware of the gargantuan effort it would take to defeat him, the fractured opposition formed an alliance that quickly faltered.\n\nOpposition parties have also accused Modi's government of trying to stifle their campaigns by arresting their leaders and freezing their funds, allegations the BJP denies. Arvind Kejriwal, a vocal Modi opponent who is the chief minister of New Delhi, was arrested in March in connection with corruption allegations, and he returned to jail Sunday after he was granted interim bail in order to campaign. He denies the charges.\n\nToday's India is run by \"a very strong, dominant BJP, which in 1984 had only got four seats in Parliament,\" said Yamini Aiyar, former chief executive of the Center for Policy Research, a highly regarded think tank in New Delhi that has been targeted by a Modi government crackdown on civil society.\n\nIn recent years especially, she said, the BJP has become \"creepingly authoritarian.\"\n\n\"Our democracy is at stake,\" Aiyar said.\n\nAccording to Freedom House, a nonprofit pro-democracy organization in Washington, elections in India are generally considered free and fair, but they are being held in an environment in which freedom of expression is shrinking. It cited the arrests and prosecutions of journalists, information manipulation using artificial intelligence and other technologies, and Indian authorities' demands that social media companies remove online content critical of the government, among other issues.\n\nModi's shaky rights record can make things awkward for Washington, which views India as an important counterweight to China. Though India is not a formal U.S. ally, it is an important defense partner and a member of strategic security groupings such as the Quad, which also includes the U.S., Australia and Japan.\n\nModi, who rarely takes live questions from journalists, pushed back against criticism at a joint news conference with President Joe Biden during a state visit to Washington last year.\n\n\"In India's democratic values, there's absolutely no discrimination, neither on basis of caste, creed or age or any kind of geographic location,\" he said.\n\nU.S. authorities also say Indian agents may have been involved in the attempted assassination last year of a Sikh activist living in New York. India denies the allegations, saying such a crime would be \"contrary to government policy.\"\n\nExperts say the U.S. relationship with Modi will continue to strengthen, regardless of who wins the U.S. presidential election in November.\n\n\"China remains the elephant in the room or the presence that is shaping the alignments and realignments across the world,\" Aiyar said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8161278434", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:20:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:20:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:19:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1837755", "title": "Key moments in India's election", "body": "As India counts over 640 million votes in the world's largest election that began on April 19, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance looks set to clinch a majority but his party was unlikely to win on its own, the running vote count showed.\n\nPeople came out in record high temperatures to elect the 543 members of the lower house of the Indian Parliament.\n\nModi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) faced a joint opposition alliance of over two dozen political parties, called the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance, or INDIA.\n\nThese are the key political moments that contributed to the result.\n\nJan 22: Modi leads the consecration of a controversial but grand temple to Lord Ram at a bitterly contested site, resulting in a wave of religious fervour that heavily favoured his Hindu nationalist BJP.\n\nJan 31: Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman presents an austere budget in an election year, projecting confidence that the Modi-led government would return to power.\n\nFeb 16: Congress, the main opposition party, said the tax department had frozen its bank accounts for a five-year-old demand for $25 million. It later got relief from the Supreme Court.\n\nMarch 14: Data revealed by the poll watchdog showed that business houses Vedanta, Airtel and Essel were among the top funders of political parties through a mechanism that allowed individuals and companies to anonymously donate money to political parties until it was scrapped by the top court.\n\nModi's BJP has garnered most of the money through this route since 2018, when it was introduced, bringing focus to the vast difference in its war chest compared to its opponents.\n\nMarch 16: The poll watchdog, the Election Commission of India, announced the world's largest election with nearly a billion registered voters would kick off on April 19.\n\nPeople would vote in seven phases over six weeks.\n\nModi said he was confident of a victory, a claim backed by poll predictions. His party leaders said the ruling alliance would win 400 of the 543 seats in parliament's lower house.\n\nMarch 22: Less than a week after the election was announced, India's financial crime-fighting agency, the Enforcement Directorate, arrested the chief minister of the capital Delhi, Arvind Kejriwal, one of the key faces of the united opposition.\n\nThis was the latest in a wave of detentions, raids and questioning of opposition politicians by India's investigative agencies.\n\nApril 21: A lower voter turnout than at the previous election in 2019 worried the BJP, and Modi changed tack in his campaign speeches.\n\nFrom largely focusing on his government's performance on economic development and welfare schemes earlier, Modi accused Congress of planning to redistribute wealth from majority Hindus to minority Muslims.\n\nApril 25: As the campaign turned more acrimonious, the Congress and the BJP complained to the Election Commission about divisive speeches by each other's leaders. The watchdog sought responses from both sides.\n\nAfter a long delay, which the opposition said allowed Modi to further violate the poll code, it asked both sides to show restraint.\n\nMay 10: Halfway through the election, Kejriwal was given bail and allowed to campaign, boosting the opposition.\n\nIn one of his first speeches, Kejriwal raised doubts about whether 73-year-old Modi would continue to be the prime minister after turning 75, an age limit the BJP has spoken about in the past.\n\nTop BJP leaders said the party has no such age limit rule, though.\n\nTo counter voter fatigue and resistance from a resurgent opposition, BJP's ideological parent, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh stepped in to help Modi's campaign.\n\nExit polls, prohibited while voting was on, predicted the BJP would record a thumping win, possibly surpassing its 2019 tally of 303 seats.", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dawn"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@dawn.com", "name":
